headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to State Street Corporation's Fourth Quarter of 2015 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. Today's discussion is being broadcast live on State Street's website at www.statestreet.com/stockholder. This conference call is also bein
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to State Street Corporation's Fourth Quarter of 2015 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. Today's discussion is being broadcast live on State Street's website at www.statestreet.com/stockholder. This conference call is also being recorded for replay. State Street's conference call is copyrighted and all rights are reserved. This call may not be recorded for rebroadcast or distribution in whole or in part without the expressed written authorization from State Street Corporation. 
The only authorized broadcast of this call will be housed on the State Street website. 
Now I would like to introduce Anthony Ostler, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations at State Street.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Crystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Chairman and CEO, Jay Hooley, who'll speak first; then Mike Bell, our CFO, will take you through our fourth quarter 2015 earnings slide presentation, which is available
componenttext:
Thank you, Crystal. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Chairman and CEO, Jay Hooley, who'll speak first; then Mike Bell, our CFO, will take you through our fourth quarter 2015 earnings slide presentation, which is available for download in the Investor Relations section of our website, www.statestreet.com. Afterwards, we'll be happy to take questions. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that today's presentation will include operating basis and other measures presented on a non-GAAP basis. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP or regulatory measures are available in the appendix to our fourth quarter 2015 slide presentation. 
In addition, today's presentation will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those statements due to a variety of important factors, such as those factors referenced in our discussion today in our 4Q '15 slide presentation under the heading Forward-Looking Statements and in our SEC filings, including the Risk Factors section of our 2014 Form 10-K. 
Our forward-looking statements speak only as of today, and we disclaim any obligation to update them, even if our views change. 
We are looking forward to our 2016 Investor Day, which will be held on Wednesday, February 24, at the Mandarin Hotel in New York City. This year's theme is the way ahead transforming State Street to extend our leadership position. 
Please contact Elizabeth Kremer at ir@statestreet.com for more information or to register. Now, let me turn it over to Jay.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony. Good morning, everyone. Our performance in the fourth quarter reflects the continued challenges presented throughout 2015, including the challenging global equity markets, particularly in emerging markets, persistent low interest rates,
componenttext:
Thanks, Anthony. Good morning, everyone. 
Our performance in the fourth quarter reflects the continued challenges presented throughout 2015, including the challenging global equity markets, particularly in emerging markets, persistent low interest rates, strengthening U.S. dollar and heightened regulatory expectations. We were successful at the energy expenses in the quarter in light of the pressure in revenues. 
In addition, we grew fee revenue in 2015 and achieved strong business results as evidenced by new asset servicing commitments of $300 billion this quarter and approximately $800 billion for the full year. 
The challenging conditions notwithstanding overall and disappointed with our full year 2015 performance and how we performed against the goals we set. We generated 2% operating basis fee revenue growth compared to 2014, which was short of our goal of 4% to 7%. 
On a constant currency basis, our operating base fee revenue was 5.3%. 
We also fell short on our objective of generating at least 200 basis points deposited fee operating leverage compared to 2014 as we posted a 79 basis point difference in growth. 
In addition to the challenging revenue environment, we experienced regulatory compliance costs and operating losses at a higher level than expected. 
Actual net interest revenue was in line with our outlook, which reflected the continued low interest rate environment in our balance sheet optimization actions. 
Our efforts to optimize have been achieved in lower excess deposits and stronger capital ratios compared to the levels at the end of 2014, positioning as well for a long-term capital plan. 
Lastly, returning capital to our shareholders remains a top priority. We increased our quarterly common share dividend to 30% per share in the second quarter of 2015, an annualized increase of nearly 14% from 2014 and we bought back $1.52 billion in common shares in 2015. 
As you may have already noted, the fourth quarter's results also include non-items in legal settlements, which we have worked hard to address and put behind us so that we can turn our complete focus on growing our business and improving our operations. Mike Bell will discuss how these items impacted our financial statements. 
Now I'd like to discuss our asset servicing and asset management businesses. We added $300 billion of new servicing commitments during the quarter across all sectors and geographies. The difficult global market environment in 2015 put significant pressure on our clients, creating a positive environment for cross-selling and clients consolidating their service business to fewer providers. 
Our asset management business experienced net outflows of $19 billion during the fourth quarter of 2015, driven primarily by net outflows of $19 billion from institutional passive mandates and $10 billion of net outflows from cash mandates, primarily from securities on the cash collateral, partially offset by $11 billion of inflows to EPS. 
Institutional net outflows were primarily driven by client asset allocation shifts in an expected redemption of 1 large supervisory client that is in sourcing our business. Redemptions by this client are expected to continue through the remainder of 2016 and assets under management associated with this client was approximately $35 billion at the end of 2015. 
Although headline net outflows were negative, annualized revenue impact on flows was a positive $10 million due to a favorable underlying business. 
During the fourth quarter of 2015, we had approximately $11 billion of positive net flows into our ETFs, including approximately $4.5 billion of inflows for , our S&P 500 ETF. We continue to invest in our ETFs for the further 13 new launches in the fourth quarter, bringing total 2015 launches to 35. 
Significant fourth quarter launches included 3 smart beta ETFs and a natural resources ETF that immediately whacked on the top 10 launches in the U.S. in 2015. 
In addition, despite our double line, total return tactical ETF was the top product launch in the U.S. in 2015 with $1.8 billion in flows. 
Overall, our SPDR ETF business had 5 of the top 10 new product launches in the U.S. with combined across all new launches of $4.3 billion. 
Going into 2016, we continue to focus on what we can control and to do our best to adjust those elements we cannot control. As we know, the start of the year in global market was not been good, but regardless of the implications to revenues, it is our objective district generate positive to the operating leverage. 
We start the year with new assets to be serviced that remained to be installed in future periods of $378 billion at December 31, and we continue to see deep and diversed pipelines, which should help our fee revenues. 
Our overall strategy is well positioned against global markets, which we believe over the long term, will deliver accelerated growth opportunities. 
Knowing we are up to a difficult in 2016, we're focused on identifying leverage to improve our performance our 2016 and help us outperform in the current macroenvironment. This includes a focus on managing expenses that is in addition to our multiyear transformation program and targeted staff reductions that we discussed on the Q3 '15 earnings call, which is called State Street Beacon. 
We currently expect State Street Beacon to generate approximately $550 million in annualized pretax net run rate expense savings by the end of 2020, with approximately $75 million of that run rate savings being achieved in 2016. 
State Street Beacon leverages the foundation built by our business operations and technology transformation program that was completed in 2014. The program will leverage our cloud infrastructure, derive next-generation platform in order to improve scale and flexibility. 
Digitization of services and solutions will enable automated access across an improvement to phases with our clients. We expect the end result of the program to produce a lower cost, client centric, integrated operating model, delivering timely information to our global exchange platforms. 
Not only will we continue our firmwide focus on expenses, but we were also looking for more ways to accelerate revenue growth through cross-selling and product innovation. 
I'm encouraged by some of the developments we've already seen through our digitization work, particularly the data solutions we can offer our customers. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Mike who will review our financial performance for the fourth quarter and then we will be available to take your call -- take your questions. Mike?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Before I begin my review of our operating basis results, our comment on 2 significant items that affected our 4Q '15 GAAP basis results is highlighted on Slide 5. First, we recorded a 4Q '15 charge of approxim
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Before I begin my review of our operating basis results, our comment on 2 significant items that affected our 4Q '15 GAAP basis results is highlighted on Slide 5. 
First, we recorded a 4Q '15 charge of approximately $17 million and a liability of approximately $240 million related to the manner in which we invoiced certain expenses to asset servicing clients, primarily in the U.S, during an 18-year period. 
The current period charge of accrual for interest that we intended to pay to the impacted clients. $223 million of the liability or $145 million after-tax relates to periods prior to the 2015 fiscal year and appears in the beginning retained earnings balance of our statement of shareholder's equity as of December 31, 2014. 
Please note all prior period financial information within the slide deck and with our -- within our earnings release and addendum have been revised to reflect the impact of the reimbursement on each prior periods presented. 
In addition, we recorded an $82 million pretax gain or $49 million after-tax related to the final payoff of a commercial real estate loan acquired as a result of the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy. 
Now please turn to Slide 9 in the slide presentation for a summary of our operating basis results for 4Q '15 and for full year of 2015. 
While 4Q '15 and 2015 full year results reflected headwinds from challenging global equity market conditions, low interest rates, a stronger U.S. dollar and heightened regulatory expenses. Full year 2015 EPS decreased 3% from 2014, reflecting lower NIR and higher expenses, particularly due to the heightened regulatory expectations, partially offset by fee growth and the continued execution of our common stock purchase program. 
Our pretax operating margin of 29.1%, an ROE of 10.7%, decreased relative to 2014. 
Compared to full year 2014, full year 2015 fee revenue was negatively impacted by the stronger U.S. dollar, largely offset by a similar benefit in total expenses. 
On a constant currency basis, these grew by 5.3% versus full year 2014. 
Turning to 4Q '15, EPS of $1.21 decreased from $1.36 in the year ago quarter, an increase from $1.15 in 3Q '15. 
Our capital ratios improved sequentially and from year-end 2014, reflecting management actions to reduce risk weighted assets and also reduce the level of excess deposits on our balance sheet. 
As we've discussed, we are particularly pleased with our progress on this priority over the second half of 2015. 
Additionally, we declared a common stock dividend of $0.34 per share and purchased approximately $350 [ph] million of our common stock. 
Turning to Slide 12, I'll discuss additional details of our operating basis revenue for 4Q '15. 
Servicing fees decreased, primarily due to the impact of the stronger U.S. dollar in the lower international equity markets, partially offset by net new business. The decrease in international equity markets, particularly in emerging markets, continues to negatively impact servicing fees. 
Compared to the year ago quarter, average daily values for the Morgan Stanley emerging market index decreased 16% while the IFA equity index was down approximately 4%. 
We estimate that approximately 10% of our servicing fees are tied to emerging markets. 
4Q '15 management fees decreased relative to a year ago, primarily due to the impact of the stronger U.S. dollar, net outflows and lower international equity markets. 
Foreign exchange revenue decreased due to lower volatility and volumes. 
Securities finance revenue increased from 4Q '14, primarily due to new business and enhanced and was higher than 3Q '15, primarily reflecting higher spreads. 
The increase in processing fees and other revenue from 4Q '15 at 3Q '15 reflects higher revenues associated to the tax advantage investments. 
It's also important to note that this line item, which has a number of elements have experienced volatility from quarter-to-quarter, was higher in 4Q '15 than normal. 
In addition, the 4Q '15 revenue also benefited from tax advanced investment seasonality, so we expect to lower in 1Q '16. 
Moving to Slide 13, you can see that our operating basis net interest revenue continue to be pressured by the prolonged low interest rate environment. The decrease in 4Q '15 average earning assets and corresponding increase in the net interest margin reflects the efforts to reduce client deposits that largely occurred towards the end of the third quarter. 
Now let's turn to Slide 14 to review 4Q '15 operating basis expenses. Importantly, total operating basis expenses decreased 3% compared to both 3Q '15 and the year ago quarter, primarily reflecting lower incentive compensation and other expenses. 
Other expenses included a $12 million settlement with the SEC related to the previously disclosed allegations of improper conduct in the solicitation of asset servicing business. 
Now turning to Slide 16 to review our capital position. As you can see, our capital ratios remain strong, which has enabled us to accomplish a key priority of returning capital to shareholders through dividends and common stock purchases. 
Importantly, at December 31, our common equity tier 1 ratio under both the Basel III fully phased-in advanced and standardized approach, increased from September 30, principally due to lower risk-weighted assets. 
The December 31 fully phased-in supplementary leverage ratio at the bank also increased to 5.7% on a fully phased-in basis, principally due to the fourth quarter effect of our proactive efforts to reduce client deposits in September. 
Moving to Slide 17. Let me review the financial details on the State Street Beacon program. We expect to achieve annual pretax net run rate expense savings of approximately $550 million by the end of 2020. 
In 2016, we expect to achieve $75 million in annual pretax net run rate expense savings, which includes the savings associated with the reduction and force that we announced in 3Q '15. 
In 2017, we expect to achieve an additional pretax net run rate expense savings of at least $125 million [ph]. 
Included in the targeted $550 million in annual pretax net run rate expense savings, our ongoing investments to support the program. 
Importantly, we expect State Street Beacon to improve our operating basis pretax profit margin to at least 31% by 2018 and to 33% by the end of 2020, all else equal. 
To accomplish our savings targets, we expect to incur restructuring charges of approximately $300 million to $400 million from 2016 through 2020, and we look forward to providing a further update at our Investor Day on February 24. 
Now let's move on to Slides 18 and 19 for the review of our 2016 financial outlook. During 2016, we remain focused on our key priorities of returning capital to shareholders, prudently managing expenses and investing in the business provide solutions to our clients. 
Although we anticipate that the environment will continue to be challenging in 2016, managing expenses is a high priority. It is our objective to generate positive fee operating leverage relative to 2015. 
Now please be aware that the year-to-date weakness in the equity markets will adversely affect total revenue. 
As a reminder, a 10% decline in global equity markets is expected to result in approximately 2% of downward pressure on our total revenue. 
While upward pressure on regulatory and compliance cost is expected to continue in 2016, we expect the growth rate of regulatory and compliance expenses to be lower than 2015. 
We also expect expense growth to be affected by new business as well as continued investments. 
Also, it's important to highlight that as in prior years, the first quarter of 2016 compensation and employee benefits expense will be seasonally higher due to the effect of the accounting treatment of equity compensation for retiring eligible employees, as well as for payroll taxes and associated benefits. 
We expect the incremental amount attributed to equity compensation for retirement-eligible employees and payroll taxes in the first quarter of 2016 to be in a range of approximately $130 million to $140 million. 
As you can see, we developed 2 scenarios for 2016 net interest revenue. The first scenario assumes market interest rates remain static at current levels. 
Under this scenario, we expect full year 2016 NIR to be in a range of approximately $2.025 billion to $2.125 billion. 
The second scenario assumes administered rates in the U.S. increased 25 basis points in both March and June and in the U.K. rates increased 25 basis points in both May and August. 
Under this scenario, we expect full year 2016 NIR to be in a range of approximately $2.1 billion to $2.2 billion. 
Additionally, we expect the 2006 [ph] operating basis tax rate to be in the range of 30% to 32%. 
Turning to the last slide. I would emphasize that returning capital to shareholders through share repurchase and dividends remains a high priority. Our 2016 capital plan remains subject to the results of the 2016 CCAR process, including a review by the Federal Reserve board. 
Now before I turn the call over to Jay, I'd like to inform all of you that David, the company Treasurer, has informed me of his intention to retire after 11 years with State Street. 
Dave has been an incredible positive force in his role as Treasurer. As the industry evolved in the regulatory environment became more complex, Dave brought the talent, processes and leadership needed to assure our continued success. We will miss him tremendously. 
Dave has agreed to stay on in an advisory capacity through July 30 to ensure an orderly transition to his responsibilities. 
And as part of our succession plan, the Board of Directors has elected Tracy Atkinson to Treasurer effective February 1. 
Now in addition to a number of other leadership goals and finance, Tracy has had oversight for global treasury for the past 5 years, so we expect her transition to the treasury role to be smooth. 
Dave has developed close relationships with many of you over the last several years. And for those of you attending our Investor Day next month, you'll have the opportunity to wish him well. 
Now let me turn the call back over to Jay.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: I mean, Mike and Jay, if you could talk a little bit about the market assumptions that you have underlying the assumption of generating stronger fee growth in 2016 versus the operating expenses and then maybe if you could just a little bit more color on what you're thinking about for operating on an absolute basis in '16 versus '15?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Brian, can you just repeat the end of that second part of your question?
componenttext: I'm sorry, Brian, can you just repeat the end of that second part of your question?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So on the expense side, if you can give us a little bit more color on how you're thinking about the absolute level of expenses -- of operating expenses in 2016 versus '15?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, that's helpful, Brian. I'll handle both those first. In terms of your question on the market assumptions, candidly, Brian, given all the uncertainty in the market environment, I'm really reluctant to give you at this point a concrete forecast,
componenttext: Okay. Yes, that's helpful, Brian. I'll handle both those first. In terms of your question on the market assumptions, candidly, Brian, given all the uncertainty in the market environment, I'm really reluctant to give you at this point a concrete forecast, and that's why we didn't include that in the prepared remarks and in the slide presentation. And I'm sure on you that the equity markets thus far in January, for example, are down high single digits and in the emerging markets even worse. And particularly without mix of business, that would be a serious headwind. So instead, we're really focused on achieving overall fee operating leverage in 2016. Now we recognize that that will be more challenging if, in fact, equity markets remain uncooperative for the rest of the year, but we'll focus on, as Jay said, what we can control. We feel good about the Beacon in savings that we'll get in 2016. We recognize that there is some upward pressure on the regulatory expenses, but we think it'll be in a lower rate than what it's been in the last -- in 2015. And so we're really looking at managing really ever expense dollar, and that really relates to your second question, which is in terms of our overall expense growth plan, it will be largely dependent upon our fee revenue. I mean, we intend to manage expenses at a lower rate than what our fees grow. And again, it will be more challenging if the environment is difficult, but that's our plan and that's why we're looking at every area of expenses. We're looking at management layers. We're looking at procurement. We're looking at outside consultants. We're looking at real estate. We're looking at low return businesses. I mean, really, we're looking at entire spectrum with the goal of getting to that positive fee operating leverage for full year 2016.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great color. And maybe just then talk about the Beacon program a little bit more for the -- you just trajectory of the $75 million and the extra net interest in the increment of 1 25 in 2017. Sort of from a timing perspective, during the year, how
componenttext: That's great color. And maybe just then talk about the Beacon program a little bit more for the -- you just trajectory of the $75 million and the extra net interest in the increment of 1 25 in 2017. Sort of from a timing perspective, during the year, how should we think about that layering in the quarters?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, let me start that. I'll let Mike answer the financial question. But let me just -- I think this help you understand the pacing. Now if we go back to 5, 6 years ago, we begin with the transformation emphasis on transformation that was really to take
componenttext: Brian, let me start that. I'll let Mike answer the financial question. But let me just -- I think this help you understand the pacing. Now if we go back to 5, 6 years ago, we begin with the transformation emphasis on transformation that was really to take our common systems, standardized processes, established Centers of Excellence. And we also introduced the public cloud and began to rewrite some of those core systems underlying those applications. Beacon takes at the next step. And I can emphasize enough that you can't take the second step unless you're successful taking the first step. The second step is too I'd say wired together all of the different systems, which in most financial institutions are not wired together on a real-time basis. So in the future state of Beacon, I'll use a simple example in our fund accounting area, we would expect that an electronic trade advice coming in from a customer would electronically and real time basis hit the security versus, the cash system, accounting system the pricing on a real time basis. So if you let your mind wonder in a if future's state, that means our whole environment becomes real time and you could dynamically price funds during the day. That will have the intended benefits of obviously cost efficiency as you replace human intervention and systems were fully integrated systems. It also reduces errors and risk, but probably most importantly and I keep finding this strong because everybody fully appreciates the value of real-time information upstream to our customers fund office for purposes of risk management, investment management, et cetera. So that's the journey. Now let me come back to a little bit more narrowly on your question. This next stage of transformation heavily involves technology development and integration. And so there's a little bit of pump binding that we were doing in 2015, which will continue in 2016 and building the systems and the integration models, which means that the trajectory of cost saves will start out slow and then build over time. So the 5 50 you can take the $75 million, 60 [ph], the 1 25 million and 70 [ph], that's just continue to build. I will also say that the trajectory in for a year will probably had a similar path. But Mike I don't know if you'd add any color to that.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Brian, the additional color that will give you, it's important to note that the $75 million is intended to be a net number in terms of our operating expense impact in full year 2016 compared to operating expenses in full year 2015. So the bottom
componenttext: Sure. So Brian, the additional color that will give you, it's important to note that the $75 million is intended to be a net number in terms of our operating expense impact in full year 2016 compared to operating expenses in full year 2015. So the bottom line is growth savings will be higher than $75 million, but there will be some net spending, which, in particular, is very helpful to position us to get some additional savings in 2017 and 2018, particularly higher than what will deliver in 2016. So the spending I would expect to hit to impact in Q1. And I agree with Jay, the savings in 2016 will mainly begin in Q2 and ramp throughout the year. So I expect a little bit of a bubble in Q1 and in net savings beginning in Q2 and accelerating through the remainder of the year.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

The $75 million in 2016, I think is not on top of the $50 million that you mentioned at the time of the headcount reduction, correct, and that you said your net -- your intention is to be in that number '16 versus '15 full year.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Both of those comments are correct, Glenn.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Awesome. Curious of talking about the investment portfolio. There was what you called ongoing repositioning of the investment portfolio. If you look at your appendix slide, it's now 64% fixed rate. So I'm curious on what's driving that change and is
componenttext: Okay. Awesome. Curious of talking about the investment portfolio. There was what you called ongoing repositioning of the investment portfolio. If you look at your appendix slide, it's now 64% fixed rate. So I'm curious on what's driving that change and is it the ratio extension on the government side? And does that mean that -- what is that mean for your rate sensitivity?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Glenn. So first of all, in terms of the repositioning in the investment portfolio, you are correct that we have down, in particular, the floating rate assets that are -- have been denominated in U.S. dollars. And the reason for that is the same thin
componenttext: Sure, Glenn. So first of all, in terms of the repositioning in the investment portfolio, you are correct that we have down, in particular, the floating rate assets that are -- have been denominated in U.S. dollars. And the reason for that is the same thing that we talked about on earlier calls in 2015, and that is -- those are primarily asset-backed securities and they are relatively low spread asset compared to, for example, U.S. Treasury's. They also don't get counted as favorably as treasuries do and they're treated relatively partially in CCAR. Because if you'll recall, the last financial crisis, spreads blew out for those assets. And therefore, the mark-to-market under the CCAR stress test is particularly unfavorable. So the U.S. dollar-based floating-rate securities in particular, which I would characterize it as the least attractive of the portfolio assets that were on the books, say, a year ago. So that's been done major driver of wanting to move away from those assets. And in terms of your question on the rate sensitivity. Again, we look at the interest rate sensitivity through several different lenses and I feel very comfortable there's been no change in our philosophy. We continue to invest through the cycle, again, working to optimize against a number of different regulatory expectations and constraints. But I would characterize it as no material change in our thinking around interest rate sensitivity.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one little follow-up on that. When you look at your margin targets, I think they included 100 basis points of hikes through the end of '17. So I'm just going to guess and say 50/50 in '16 and '17. If the math on the impacts to the margin of rat
componenttext: Okay. Just one little follow-up on that. When you look at your margin targets, I think they included 100 basis points of hikes through the end of '17. So I'm just going to guess and say 50/50 in '16 and '17. If the math on the impacts to the margin of rates don't change the same as the math that you gave us on the static and higher rate scenario? I mean, with all the same number, can you just back into that see that the impact on margin targets if rates don't change.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Glenn, I think that's fair. Be go that's going to provide an update at the February Investor Day around the longer term NIM ranges, including static, including idea of getting to something 3/5 [ph] long-term interest rate structure. I think the main
componenttext: Yes, Glenn, I think that's fair. Be go that's going to provide an update at the February Investor Day around the longer term NIM ranges, including static, including idea of getting to something 3/5 [ph] long-term interest rate structure. I think the main pivotal point Glenn, though, that I want to make this morning is that we do expect that the Beacon savings will fall to our bottom line. We expect that the Beacon savings will be additive to the profit margins. So when we say all else equal, we know that there'll be other things going on in the world that are impacting margins. I think that you mentioned the NIR. NIR obviously can be separately highlighted and analyzed. But the bottom line was commented were making most. We do expect the Beacon savings to be additive.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Olson with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Olson with Jefferies.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Mike, you had good improvement on the Tier 1 leverage ratio, which is your limiting ratio as you get into CCAR '16. And obviously, with the challenges on the environment translating the challenges for your earnings run rate, I'm just wondering, acros
componenttext: Hey, Mike, you had good improvement on the Tier 1 leverage ratio, which is your limiting ratio as you get into CCAR '16. And obviously, with the challenges on the environment translating the challenges for your earnings run rate, I'm just wondering, across of restructuring charges coming in and affecting net income, can you remind us again when you think about CCAR going forward, how do you think about the payout ratio? Do you think about it on a net income number or do you think about it on an operating number? And how does this change in the environment, if at all change your desire to get to the rest of the buyback to the extent you get approval and change your thinking at all for going forward?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ken. I appreciate the question. First, let me just comment on your first piece because I think it was a very important point. And that is as you can imagine, for CCAR, reducing our excess deposits by approximately $36 billion over the second half of
componenttext: Sure, Ken. I appreciate the question. First, let me just comment on your first piece because I think it was a very important point. And that is as you can imagine, for CCAR, reducing our excess deposits by approximately $36 billion over the second half of 2015 is particularly helpful for us going into the CCAR. And obviously, we don't have the CCAR instructions yet, the specifics around the stress test. But any way you slice it, we're really pleased with the progress that we made and we feel good about the position will be in for the next CCAR. And what pretty good relative to what we've been in if we hadn't reduced the deposits. On your specific question around the income, those income measures are very relevant. The net income measure is relevant and also the operating income is relevant. First, the operating income really represents, Ken, our best estimate of what our run rate earnings are. So if you think about what the next 3 or 4 years are going to be, the operating income is what we think of as the starting point ideally to grow over the next several years. So I think it's a very important data point for the upcoming CCAR. Having said that,, net income obviously impacts capital. And so what -- to go on that one issue, the restructuring charges for the FX settlement charges that we took in first and second quarter of 2015 or even this out-of-pocket issue, all of that decreased capital, essentially dollar per dollar, which is why it's very important for us to be managing capital as aggressively as we can because at the end of the day, what we believe to be our binding constraint is actually our overall capital ratios and in particular, the next CCAR, test will show what does that capital position look like under the stress test? So maybe longer way to answer than you may have been looking for, but the bottom line is both of those income numbers matter because the operating income will be more predictive and we expect to be more predictive of what our future income will be, but the net income impacts the capital position that we're sitting here with today dollar per dollar.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just get a follow-up just on the balance sheet. you said $36 billion [ph] reduction in the second half. So if you just -- what was the excess deposits at the end of the year? And would you continue to expect additional lowdown of load
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just get a follow-up just on the balance sheet. you said $36 billion [ph] reduction in the second half. So if you just -- what was the excess deposits at the end of the year? And would you continue to expect additional lowdown of loads going forward or have you kind of work to the point that where it's more manageable and perhaps you won't need -- well, I guess the question is, do you have any incremental after all these reduction for any preferreds?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Ken, first answer your factual question. We estimate that under our historical methodology, our excess deposits average approximately $26 billion in Q4. Now as we've talked about before, that's the historical definition under the LCR rules, some
componenttext: Sure. So Ken, first answer your factual question. We estimate that under our historical methodology, our excess deposits average approximately $26 billion in Q4. Now as we've talked about before, that's the historical definition under the LCR rules, some of what we thought as operational deposits no longer account. So at some point were going to flip over to a definition of nonoperational deposits that, for example, would include the deposits we had with hedge funds and private equity relationships. We need to do know those our mobile operations with our customer relationships there for's LCR purposes the unfounded is nonoperational. But to answer your question factually, $26 billion versus our average at Q2 with $62 billion. So a $36 billion reduction there. On your question on the push harder in the -- about the issue around the press. Well, first of all, Ken, the short answer would be that really pleased with what we've accomplished. And this is not been a trivial exercise. This is an issue that's a sensitive one for a number of our clients. And so the fact that we feel good and we got to a win-win with our clients after these -- after all these discussions, we think that is to a little bit point. So I would say at this point, we don't feel compelled to drive more off of the balance sheet relative to where they were, for example, in Q4, but it is something that we're going to monitor carefully. It is something that subject to market conditions. The situation in Europe, for example, is just not helpful at all. I mean, it used to be cutting the minus 30, talking about possibly cutting further, credit spreads have come in dramatically in Europe because of the quantity of. So for all those regions, I think we have to continue to monitor this. But at this point, I feel good about where we are. Now your question on preps is one of those I can't yet answer fully because we don't have the CCAR stress test. I mean, obviously, we're in much better position. But until we see the dynamics around that stress test and go through that modeling over the next 60 days, I'm just not in a position to give you an estimate at this point.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Luke Montgomery with Bernstein.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to take another quick stab at Brian's question on the 2016 outlook. Maybe you answered it, but it wasn't clear to me. When you established the positive fee operating leverage goal, did you factor in the decline we had in the market share to
componenttext: I just wanted to take another quick stab at Brian's question on the 2016 outlook. Maybe you answered it, but it wasn't clear to me. When you established the positive fee operating leverage goal, did you factor in the decline we had in the market share to date or are you assuming year-end market levels?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Luke, it's Mike. We certainly factored in what we know about markets as of today. And I think the down, we feel like there's more opportunities for improvement over the course of the year. But I think the most important thing is that we are focused, Luke,
componenttext: Luke, it's Mike. We certainly factored in what we know about markets as of today. And I think the down, we feel like there's more opportunities for improvement over the course of the year. But I think the most important thing is that we are focused, Luke, on controlling expenses. That's bad and that we can -- that's really best within our control. And we do expect, again, barring a catastrophe in terms of further deterioration in markets to be able to get to that net all-in positive fee operating leverage from the full year. Now, again, it is something that you this is something to market conditions, it's probably something that we're going to want to update you on at the Investor Day in February, at each subsequent quarter. They're our focus. And Luke, I guarantee you the management team is really galvanized around this collectively. Our focus is to generate positive fee operating leverage for the full year.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a follow-up on the balance sheet side. I know it depends on client behavior. But apart from that, are you assuming any growth from the current earning assets of $200 billion in your guidance for 2016?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a follow-up on the balance sheet side. I know it depends on client behavior. But apart from that, are you assuming any growth from the current earning assets of $200 billion in your guidance for 2016?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Luke, we anticipate a small decline in the average earning assets over the course of the full year, but I think the more important point to the point that you just made, which is in large part, it will be a function of market interest rates and just overa
componenttext: Luke, we anticipate a small decline in the average earning assets over the course of the full year, but I think the more important point to the point that you just made, which is in large part, it will be a function of market interest rates and just overall market conditions. But our fee that if the fed funds rate increases by an additional 50 basis points, if Bank of England increases by an additional 50 basis points that a good chunk of those excess deposits remain will naturally come off the balance sheet. And we do expect growth in our core business. So we would expect some growth in the operations deposits from growth in our core business. But I would say net-net, I would expect that the average earning assets to be modestly less by year-end 2016. Now importantly, if there's a crisis again, God forbid, all bets are off. I mean, we are a safe haven in terms of the crisis. Hopefully, that's not going to happen, but that would be another wildcard.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to understand your guidance a little bit more. So your target had been to grow fee revenues expenses by 200 basis points. Last year, you came in at 79 basis points. And now your target is simply, I guess, 1 basis point, right, just 1 positive ope
componenttext: I wanted to understand your guidance a little bit more. So your target had been to grow fee revenues expenses by 200 basis points. Last year, you came in at 79 basis points. And now your target is simply, I guess, 1 basis point, right, just 1 positive operating leverage. So on the one hand, you were disappointed that you didn't meet the target last year. On the other hand, the new target is basically just positive operating leverage. So I just want to reconcile those thoughts of being disappointed, but again, lowering the target quite a bit. And I think I heard the reason. You had a lower stock market, lower rates in Europe currencies and regulatory costs, but rather here, you validated to add or elaborate on it.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. It's Mike. I'll start and if Jay wants to add. Importantly, Mike, we want to get every dollar positive fee operating leverage that we can in 2016. And we are committed, as we talked about, to aggressively managing expenses to work through towa
componenttext: Sure, Mike. It's Mike. I'll start and if Jay wants to add. Importantly, Mike, we want to get every dollar positive fee operating leverage that we can in 2016. And we are committed, as we talked about, to aggressively managing expenses to work through towards achieving that goal. But it's the point that you made. I mean, with equity markets off almost 10% and we're not even through to January yet, it just seemed to us to be irresponsible to put a specific number out there even in light of how confident we feel in Beacon. So again, as I said to a couple of further questions, I'm sure that this is something that will talk about through the course of the year, but it's not a question of lowering our expectations. It's being cognizant of the environment and focusing aggressively on what we can control.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as far as the actual expense guidance with project Beacon. I mean, so last year, your core expenses is were $7,520,000,000. And so for this year's, we simply subtract $75 million since that's a net number or that doesn't reflect the additional expense
componenttext: And as far as the actual expense guidance with project Beacon. I mean, so last year, your core expenses is were $7,520,000,000. And so for this year's, we simply subtract $75 million since that's a net number or that doesn't reflect the additional expense pressures?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it doesn't reflect, for example, expenses that I would expect to bring on. It's service of the new business that we're winning out in the market. So that's why I wouldn't -- I stay away from just what expense number and it's going to largely depend
componenttext: Well, it doesn't reflect, for example, expenses that I would expect to bring on. It's service of the new business that we're winning out in the market. So that's why I wouldn't -- I stay away from just what expense number and it's going to largely depend upon our fee revenue growth. Since we're in the service business, we tend to need to bring on servicing capabilities to service on the revenue. As I mentioned earlier, now the regulatory-related expenses will likely increase, we don't think that they will increase as much as they did in 2015, but that's why it really, Mike, we're focused on fee operating leverage, positive fee operating leverage as being the overall goal, recognizing that the equity markets in January immediately make that a challenging objective.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, the way we look at it, what was your pretax margin for 2015, especially since you're looking to take that quite a bit higher?
componenttext: And then lastly, the way we look at it, what was your pretax margin for 2015, especially since you're looking to take that quite a bit higher?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Beatty with Bank of America.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask about the NIR guidance and in particular, you've been asked about some assumptions. You've noted in your presentation the impact of foreign exchange on NIR. So I'm just wondering, what kind of your base case for the NIR scenarios was in term
componenttext: Wanted to ask about the NIR guidance and in particular, you've been asked about some assumptions. You've noted in your presentation the impact of foreign exchange on NIR. So I'm just wondering, what kind of your base case for the NIR scenarios was in terms of currency flat from here or something different from that? And then maybe how sensitive that number would be to currency?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in terms of the NIR ranges that we provided, it essentially assumes today's foreign exchange currency rates. Now again, we recognize that that's wildcard. And as an example, if we look at full year 2015 versus full year 2014, we estimate that NIR
componenttext: Sure. So in terms of the NIR ranges that we provided, it essentially assumes today's foreign exchange currency rates. Now again, we recognize that that's wildcard. And as an example, if we look at full year 2015 versus full year 2014, we estimate that NIR was negatively impacted by $54 million as a result of the stronger U.S. dollar over the course of 2015. So obviously, I don't expect it that U.S. dollar will strengthen further, as we said, that kind of magnitude that we saw in 2015, but that would give you at least a sense of the magnitude if we had to repeat of that level of our strengthening, that's the ballpark that we could see as an additional headwind with NIR. Obviously, the Europe turnaround got stronger in particular, that will be helpful.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the portfolio hasn't been to be positioned such that the currency effect will aggressively differ.
componenttext: Okay. So the portfolio hasn't been to be positioned such that the currency effect will aggressively differ.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then turning to the new business win in asset servicing, you mentioned the kind of positive mix shift in the asset management despite the negative flows, there was a positive revenue impact. So I'm just wondering asset servicing in the new wins
componenttext: Great. And then turning to the new business win in asset servicing, you mentioned the kind of positive mix shift in the asset management despite the negative flows, there was a positive revenue impact. So I'm just wondering asset servicing in the new wins, how that mix is kind of shaping up? And also in terms of implementation, how soon you would expect the current backlog to be installed?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Adam. Let me take that. So I mentioned the $300 billion-ish of new commitments on the asset servicing side. a little bit unusually, that was tilted to the U.S. with 2 50 of the 300 in U.S. And then I think you had 35 15 EMEA and Asia Pacific. So to
componenttext: Sure, Adam. Let me take that. So I mentioned the $300 billion-ish of new commitments on the asset servicing side. a little bit unusually, that was tilted to the U.S. with 2 50 of the 300 in U.S. And then I think you had 35 15 EMEA and Asia Pacific. So to me, the -- it's a little bit indicative of some of the pressure that the asset management industry is under -- not that it's not global, but it's probably a little bit more acute in the U.S. And so the opportunity to do more deeper level of outsourcing as well as consolidate more activities with State Street is probably in underlying fee there. From a -- you also asked about the backlog, which again is a little bit higher, at $380 billion. And I think that's probably historically been on the 200 to 300 range. It's elevated because there's some bigger chunk year deals that have a little longer implementation timeline. Those should layer in the first couple of quarters of 2016. Additionally, I would say from an outlook pipeline standpoint, actually quite good, with some different call it from the U.S. to the Europe, Asia. Asia continues to be moving in a pretty positive line. Europe has been dominated by the offshore markets, which is where are the actions coming from. So to the U.S., it's a combination of hedge. As I mentioned earlier, the traditional managers who are really grappling with fee pressure and flows and where an opportunity for them to streamline the operation and get more efficient.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And am I right in assuming that asset management outsourcing is relatively high fee versus the current mix or not so much?
componenttext: All right. And am I right in assuming that asset management outsourcing is relatively high fee versus the current mix or not so much?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Asset management outsourcing broadly would be very consistent with the existing business from a fee and margin standpoint, if I heard your question right.
componenttext: Asset management outsourcing broadly would be very consistent with the existing business from a fee and margin standpoint, if I heard your question right.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brennan Hawken with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brennan Hawken with UBS.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up first on the Beacon question and the $75 million. Sorry to come back to it. I just want to make sure I understand. You expect it to be a net number, but you also talked about growing regulatory expenses albeit at a slowing rate. So
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up first on the Beacon question and the $75 million. Sorry to come back to it. I just want to make sure I understand. You expect it to be a net number, but you also talked about growing regulatory expenses albeit at a slowing rate. So does that $75 million net reflect what your expectations on the regulatory front or is that regulatory headwind will be at a declining rate a separate issue? And if so, can you help us frame the regulatory headwind by letting us know how much -- what the growth rate was full year '15 versus '14?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Brennan, it's Mike. First, it's the latter. The regulatory expenses, regulatory-related expenses, we look at as a separate category from Beacon. So I do expect that some piece, although it's certainly not, all but anything, but some piece of the Bea
componenttext: Sure. Brennan, it's Mike. First, it's the latter. The regulatory expenses, regulatory-related expenses, we look at as a separate category from Beacon. So I do expect that some piece, although it's certainly not, all but anything, but some piece of the Beacon savings would be offset by the additional growth in regulatory-related expenses that we expect for 2016. And as we've talked about in the past, Brennan, I've walked in to try to give a very specific number on regulatory-related expenses. I just think that at this point, it's truly embedded in the enterprise. I mean, we're all spending more time and attention on regulatory related issues. And I just think, I mean, it would think this sort of massive time and motion of kind of study to give you a number that would accurately portray it. I mean, it's fair to say the significant upward pressure, although as I said, it's really fair to say that we still expect the bulk of the $75 million of the Beacon savings to drop as to the bottom line. Again, all the things equal the conversation that we had earlier.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. I get that it's a tough one to try to frame and then we're in. Uncharted waters, just figured I'd give it a shot. Second question is on the asset management business. So the -- just curious if you could help us think about the ETF blows, you h
componenttext: Sure, sure. I get that it's a tough one to try to frame and then we're in. Uncharted waters, just figured I'd give it a shot. Second question is on the asset management business. So the -- just curious if you could help us think about the ETF blows, you had a good December, which certainly helped out on the quarter. But seem like outflows were a little bit of a struggle in ETF front for the SPDR's platform in 2015. So obviously, you guys are working to try to launch new products as an offset there. But can you give us maybe broadly and strategically whether or not you think that's sufficient? Is it all just vanguard and price competition? And given how the legacy for the previous SPDR spot was positioned, you're more subject to that type of competition, which is why you're going in the new direction? And how should we think about seasonal outflows, which is it in the other side of just the seasonal inflows in December? Any color you could give us on that front just to help us model for this quarter will be great.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, Brennan. I'm happy to pick that one up. Let me get some give you some numbers and then maybe I'll get to some more of qualitative questions as to where we are in our journey to make ETFs a more important business for us. If I look at full year 2015
componenttext: Great, Brennan. I'm happy to pick that one up. Let me get some give you some numbers and then maybe I'll get to some more of qualitative questions as to where we are in our journey to make ETFs a more important business for us. If I look at full year 2015, our net outflows were approximately $23 billion. Our net outflows this time, which is S&P 500 was outflows of $31 [ph] billion. So if you take the influence of the S&P 500 out of the mix, we were net up 8 [ph]. And we were net up 11 in the fourth quarter. So there's a -- if you look at trends and you normalize for the S&P 500, which is a very large fund with very low fees that move a lot because people uses this for liquidity purposes all over the globe. You're right in that we have -- we've been on a 2-year journey to invest in our ETF platform in nearly 2 directions. One is that initially, our ETF orientation was more to institutional market. We've ramped up considerably intermediary sales force over the last couple of years. And the other place that we focused is on product. And our focus on product, which will gets at maybe at the heart of part your question has been away from the more commoditized by product and more to the higher revenue yielding products. And so you saw some evidence in my quote. In 2015, we had 5 of the top U.S. new products in the marketplace. And in fact, we had 37% of the flows into new U.S. ETFs came to SSgA in 2015. So to me, very good evidence that our strategy have not only building up our distribution sales force, but reorienting our product towards the higher yielding products. I also referenced the smart beta fees, which you tend to read about a lot lately. We think that's a big deal, which is to take ETFs and bond over asset allocation model and package them and sell them through large into intermediary market. We introduced 3 new smart beta ETFs or model portfolios with another name given to that in the fourth quarter. And then the final point I would make -- next to final point is that we continue to be the only of the large players that are willing to open our platform to outside strategies. So the most recent would be the double line fund, which generated -- which is the largest new fund launch in the U.S. in 2015 at $1.8 billion. So I think we're doing all the things -- we're executing on all the things that we set out to execute. And I think we're on a good track to make ETF not only a growth engine with an SSgA, but a bigger part of overall State Street. Pleased with the progress.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Jim Mitchell with Buckingham Research.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: One quick follow-up on expenses just so I fully understand what you're saying. If fee revenue was flat or down, can you have expenses down? Or is there a presumption of fee income growth despite the equity market decline so far?
componenttext: One quick follow-up on expenses just so I fully understand what you're saying. If fee revenue was flat or down, can you have expenses down? Or is there a presumption of fee income growth despite the equity market decline so far?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, it's Mike. First of all, obviously, given the uncertainty around the environment, it's difficult to answer your question definitively with full confidence. But I stand by in what we talked about earlier, which is we do expect to manage expenses in a
componenttext: Jim, it's Mike. First of all, obviously, given the uncertainty around the environment, it's difficult to answer your question definitively with full confidence. But I stand by in what we talked about earlier, which is we do expect to manage expenses in a lower rate above growth in the revenue. At this point, I do expect as long as markets are reasonably cooperative, we're still in depth with full year net fee revenue growth. But again, as we talked about earlier, it's something that we probably need to continue to update you on over the course of the year. But our expectation is to manage expenses aggressively and to manage those to a low growth rate than the fee revenue.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. Just on your NII guidance would 2 [ph] 8 [ph] hikes. The low end is actually lower than the high end of your no additional rate hikes. It seems pretty modest impact from 2 8 hikes despite, I guess, the 10-Q disclosure. So is that a change in
componenttext: Fair enough. Just on your NII guidance would 2 [ph] 8 [ph] hikes. The low end is actually lower than the high end of your no additional rate hikes. It seems pretty modest impact from 2 8 hikes despite, I guess, the 10-Q disclosure. So is that a change in deposit outflow assumptions or is it just timing in terms of the remaining 6 months of the year versus the full 12 months and beyond? How should we think about your NII leverage given your 10-Q disclosures, which are more much more significant?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim. Well, first of all, the 10-Q disclosures, importantly, number one, assume no client behavior change. And we do anticipate with a couple more hikes for excess deposits in particular to come off the balance sheet. Second, importantly, the 10-Q di
componenttext: Sure, Jim. Well, first of all, the 10-Q disclosures, importantly, number one, assume no client behavior change. And we do anticipate with a couple more hikes for excess deposits in particular to come off the balance sheet. Second, importantly, the 10-Q disclosures are for a consistent interest rate change globally. And I would tell you that is that is, in my view, highly unlikely to be the case in Europe. I mean, used to be now has cut rates to minus 30. I just talk about cutting that further. As I mentioned earlier, the credit spread compression that we've seen in Europe because of the quantitative easing program has been significant. So I mean, just to give you a -- perhaps a number of that to help you with our modeling, we estimate that on an all-in basis this year versus full year 2015 that the euro NIR is expected to decline by approximately $40 [ph] million year-over-year, and that's assuming the interest rates in Europe where they sit today, does not factor in fully additional deterioration. So yes, it is the case that we would expect this to be stronger in the U.S. but that's a headwind. And again, relative to full year 2015, the decline in the excess deposits would also be a headwind in NIR. On the other hand, obviously, some positive versus having issue with the press to pay for those.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay, that's awful. And then last question for me. Securities lending, saw short-term spreads widened quite a bit in the fourth quarter. That seems to be continuing so far. Was most of that impact already felt in 4Q or should we see some further be
componenttext: Right. Okay, that's awful. And then last question for me. Securities lending, saw short-term spreads widened quite a bit in the fourth quarter. That seems to be continuing so far. Was most of that impact already felt in 4Q or should we see some further benefits to wider spreads if they stay where they are in 1Q on the SEC lending side?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jim, it's obviously a little bit early to give you definitive guidelines from SEC lending for the first half of the year. I would say that we feel very positive about the uptick in SEC lending in Q4. We -- specifically, we saw an increase in the ave
componenttext: Well, Jim, it's obviously a little bit early to give you definitive guidelines from SEC lending for the first half of the year. I would say that we feel very positive about the uptick in SEC lending in Q4. We -- specifically, we saw an increase in the average assets on loan, both enhanced custody business as well as of the agency business. We saw higher spreads, particularly on U.S. equities and believe that the demand for a short interest and in particular, for specials in Q4 help significantly. I wouldn't disappoint -- I mean, I see nothing to believe that that is going to come down. On the other hand, I wouldn't try to project additional growth since Q4 was the strongest that was.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jay, can you share with us -- you mentioned about the new program Beacon step 2 and you needed to take step 1, of course, to get the step 2. Is there going to be a step 3? Is this an evolving process? I know this goes out to 2020, which is a ways away. Bu
componenttext: Jay, can you share with us -- you mentioned about the new program Beacon step 2 and you needed to take step 1, of course, to get the step 2. Is there going to be a step 3? Is this an evolving process? I know this goes out to 2020, which is a ways away. But when you look out longer term, is this just an ongoing fact of this business that you've got to constantly have these big programs?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say largely, Gerard, I would view this being a 2-stage event, that stage 1 complete, stage 2 just commenced. They will always be opportunities to apply technology at this business, both to generate revenue opportunities and expense saves. But in m
componenttext: I would say largely, Gerard, I would view this being a 2-stage event, that stage 1 complete, stage 2 just commenced. They will always be opportunities to apply technology at this business, both to generate revenue opportunities and expense saves. But in my vision, this Beacon, since we have gone through the staging of standardization and Centers of Excellence, rewriting a lot of the applications, I think once we wire them together, for me, the Holy Grail is to create an environment within State Street that's all real-time. And if it's all real time, you have minimal human intervention, you have all the intended benefits of it. And in my mind, as we get out to 2020, we should largely be there, not that there won't be -- I'd say if there was a stage 3, it would be more revenue-oriented. Once we can trade a real-time infrastructure here, the opportunity to build systems, to build capabilities to generate global exchange type opportunity is probably where the next big move is. But again, it's not cost-oriented. It's more how you take the data on analytics that have created in this Beacon environment and create information-based services to our customers that would be obviously chargeable.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now is the technology that you're anticipating to get this going, is it all available now or are you anticipating there will be even more advances in technology 3 years from now that will make deposits even better for the customers?
componenttext: Now is the technology that you're anticipating to get this going, is it all available now or are you anticipating there will be even more advances in technology 3 years from now that will make deposits even better for the customers?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, it's a great question. And I would say we have a plan with a lot of detail on it. But I would fully expect that as we get out in years that technology advancements will cause us to make adjustments for the plan. And I'll just give you an example
componenttext: You know, it's a great question. And I would say we have a plan with a lot of detail on it. But I would fully expect that as we get out in years that technology advancements will cause us to make adjustments for the plan. And I'll just give you an example, Gerard, that hopefully will resonate. When we went into the ITOT, as we we call it, we were very determined that we wanted to create a cloud environment. And we're also very convinced that the only cloud environment that was appropriate would be a private cloud, meaning that we would own and operate and control it. I think in today is quite a bit different. We would envision that some of the test modules that we would build, we might from a them public cloud that as long as your encrypted data, you're a safe running it out in the public cloud as you are in a private cloud. And I say if you talk to people and are deeply involved in this world, you'd find that to be a fairly meaningful shift in philosophy. So within our Beacon plan, some of that has brought in. But I think for us to imagine what the technology enablements will be 5 years out is pretty tough to do. I think, though, it gets back to a point that I made in new reinforce, which is unfortunately you can't leap frog, so you have to modify along the way. And we think we've got a plan that not only enables us to get to that future real estate, but it will also allow us to take advantage of advances in technology as the day unfolds over the next 5 years.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Great. Couple of questions. One, why is the client leaving? And two, $35 billion, is that a really big customer, medium-sized customer, small customer? How would you characterize that type of client?

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I would say it's a customer really have a long-term multidimensional relationship. This is one component of it. I would characterize it as a small-ish kind of customer. And I say that because it's all passive assets. So it's a little bit my SPDR,
componenttext: Sure. So I would say it's a customer really have a long-term multidimensional relationship. This is one component of it. I would characterize it as a small-ish kind of customer. And I say that because it's all passive assets. So it's a little bit my SPDR, S&P 500 example where the headline numbers stay, but the revenues associated with it are not significant. The other point I would make, Gerard, is that while not a trend, it's not exceptional that somebody would say, I want to run my passive assets myself and in this particular customer is a bank the side of that as opposed outsourcing that to us, they wouldn't sources for themselves.

componenttext: Brian, it's Mike. First, this does relate overbilling that we've had historically. In fact, it goes back to the late 1990s. So as a result, rather than charging the Q4 2015 P&L with that amount, we have revised the other financial statements that we provided this quarter to basically make an adjustment to the most recent P&L periods and also to the retained earnings account for year-end '14. So this is reflected in that retained earnings statements. So it's already negatively impacted of our capital, that piece for the liability that I talked about in the prepared remarks, that is behind us at this point. Now obviously, as you can imagine, other things can develop, but at this point, that's already reflected in the balance sheet and in the prior earnings periods.

headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just on the operating leverage guidance. headline: State Street Corporation, 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016

componenttext: Well, importantly, Brian, we're looking, number one, at expenses across the board. And I would anticipate that between net new business and potential growth in, for example, global markets revenue that we would still be able to get those. But again, it's something that's evolving situations as the market environment, which is challenging as it is.
