headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the State Street Corporations First Quarter of 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. Today's discussion is being broadcast live on State Street's website at www.statestreet.com/stockholder. This conference call is also be
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the State Street Corporations First Quarter of 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. Today's discussion is being broadcast live on State Street's website at www.statestreet.com/stockholder. This conference call is also being recorded for replay. State Street's conference call is copyrighted and all rights are reserved. This call may not be recorded for rebroadcast or distribution in whole or in part without the express written authorization from State Street Corporation. The only authorized broadcast of this call will be housed on the State Street website.
Now I would like to introduce Anthony Ostler, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations at State Street.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Thereese. Good morning, and thank you, all, for joining us. On our call today, our Chairman and CEO, Jay Hooley, will speak first; then Mike Bell, our CFO, will take you through our first quarter 2016 earnings slide presentation, which is availabl
componenttext:
Thanks, Thereese. Good morning, and thank you, all, for joining us. On our call today, our Chairman and CEO, Jay Hooley, will speak first; then Mike Bell, our CFO, will take you through our first quarter 2016 earnings slide presentation, which is available for download in the Investor Relations section of our website, www.statestreet.com. Afterwards, we'll be happy to take questions. [Operator Instructions]
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that today's presentation will include operating basis and other measures presented on a non-GAAP basis. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP or regulatory measures are available in the appendix to our first quarter 2016 slide presentation. In addition, today's presentation will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those statements due to a variety of important factors, such as those factors referenced in our discussion today in our 1Q '16 slide presentation under the heading Forward-Looking Statements and in our SEC filings, including the Risk Factors section of our 2015 Form 10-K. Our forward-looking statements speak only as of today, and we disclaim any obligation to update them, even if our views change. as of the past couple of quarters, we have instituted a new financial results on the fourth Wednesday of the month following each quarter end. As such, we expect to hold our second quarter earnings call on Wednesday, July 27, 2016.
Now, let me turn it over to Jay.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone. Despite the challenging environment, I'm pleased with the progress we've made during the quarter on the 5 strategic priorities I outlined for you at our Investor Day in February. These priorities will help us t
componenttext:
Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone. Despite the challenging environment, I'm pleased with the progress we've made during the quarter on the 5 strategic priorities I outlined for you at our Investor Day in February. These priorities will help us to transform State Street, compete in the new environment and deliver value on the short-term. As a reminder, these priorities are one to become a digital leader in financial services, to drive growth from our core franchise, to invest in new products that will enhance revenue and drive differentiation, increase our focus on expense management and then leverage our strong capital position to continue to return capital to shareholders.
As you can see on Slide 4 of the slide deck, we've outlined some new highlights of our progress so far this year against those 5 priorities. First, on becoming a digital leader in financial services. We are investing and becoming a digital leader in financial services through State Street Beacon. Our journey to digitize core processes will deliver an enhanced client experience and generate $550 million in annual pretax net run-rate expense savings by the end of 2020. Our clients are already beginning to see the results of our investments through a faster and more consistent delivery of services, impacting our client operations and driving improved ranking in distribution channels. We are also actively engaged in evaluating new technologies such as [indiscernible].
We remain on track to achieve State Street Beacon-related annualized run rate savings at $100 million by the end of this year. That amount will be reflected in our 2017 results. As we indicated, it could be to case at our Investor Day, we could take a pretax restructuring charge of $97 million and the course of first quarter related to Beacon.
Second, we expect our core franchise to continue to deliver growth given our leading positions in attractive markets. Although our first quarter key revenue reflect the challenging market environment experienced in the early part of the year, I'm encouraged by the size of stability in March and the strength of our pipeline across the firm. The first quarter included new asset service of $264 billion at approximately $400 billion of service commitments remaining at quarter-end to be installed from current and prior periods.
I want to highlight a win that our global services group in Asia-Pacific recently finalized. In early March, we to be the massive facilities for Australia's third-largest superannuation fund, First Aid Super. This new relationship will also expand in our global markets and global chains businesses. Of note, State Street now services 4 of the 7 largest super funds and what is a high growth sector for us in Australia. I'm also pleased to say that our asset management business had met inflows of $13 billion with expected annualized net new revenue of $11 million during the quarter, providing the strongest quarterly net flow in annualized revenue results since the fourth quarter of 2014. Net activity was driven primarily by $7 billion of inflows from EPS and $11 billion of inflows into cash products.
Third,, we believe continuous investment in new products and solutions will enhance revenue and drive differentiation. Our recent agreement to acquire ETF Management support that strategy to invest in higher growth and return businesses. GE Asset Management significantly requisition I outsource CIO market, which is one of the faster growing segments of the asset management business. Additionally, GE Asset management expands SSGA alternative capabilities while enhancing our equity and fixed income teams, which part of the solution set combined with our client base. Most importantly, GE Asset Management is a high quality organization with strong cultural with SSGA. And this transaction is an endorsement of our ongoing strong long-term relationship with the GE. We expect this acquisition to be accretive in the first 12 months of operation.
On an ongoing basis, we evaluate products that are not meaning strategic or financial expectations. We made a decision during the quarter to exit our Futures Clearing business. At the begin of the second quarter, we completed the sale of the branded foreign exchange benchmark business to Thomson Reuters. These and other ongoing return to capital actions are improving our efficiency, strategic focus and ROE over the medium to long-term.
Innovation is a critical differentiator in the competitive ETF segment and a key focus for SSGA. Our SSGA SPDR business introduced 13 new funds during the quarter, including the SSGA gender diversity ETF. She is the first self index ETF and this development was inspired by efforts to move diversity in corporate America, and seeks to track performance of the SSGA gender diversity index, which comprises largely U.S. large-cap companies with the highest levels within their sectors of gender diversity on the boards of directors and in their senior leadership.
Forth, we are increasing our focus on expense management. Our results this quarter reflected our commitment to manage expenses with first quarter operating expenses flat compared to the same period a year ago, and also flat excluding the seasonal impact of equity compensation for retirement eligible employees in Taylor Texas compared to the fourth quarter of 2015. We continue to make expense discipline core to our culture and current employees to embrace its mindset and identify ways we can reduce costs across the enterprise. Looking at everything from travel to consultant spend.
As I noted earlier, State Street's contributed to our expense management effort, and we are on track to generate at least $100 million in annualized pre-tax net run-rate expense savings this year from the program.
And fifth, we're leveraging our strong capital position to continue to return capital to shareholders. By June -- first quarter '16, common stock dividend was $0.34 per share, and we purchased approximately $325 million of our common stock. We expect to repurchase up to $390 million of our common stock in 2Q '16.
In this review for you we will continue to focus our attention and effort in 2016 on our strategic priorities. We expect this will allow us to generate positive fee revenue growth which is to achieve our objective of generating positive fee basis operating leverage this year balance [indiscernible] 2015.
2 weeks ago, the Federal Reserve and FDIC released a review of our July 2015 ROT signature. Both the Federal Reserve and FDIC know we have made improvement over our prior plans, but determined that our 2015 resolution plan is not credible. While disappointed with the findings, we're committed to addressing the issues in advancing our resolution plan as our business and regulatory requirements evolve. In fact, ongoing communications with the regulator and our focus on addressing all the deficiencies duly identified by the Federal Reserve and the FDIC by October 1st, 2016.
Now I'll turn the call over to Mike who will review our financial performance for the first quarter, and then we'll both be available to take your questions.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Good morning, everyone. This morning, before I start my review of our operating basis results, I'd like to note that our GAAP basis results for the first quarter, included pretax restructuring cost of $97 million related to State Street Be
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay. Good morning, everyone. This morning, before I start my review of our operating basis results, I'd like to note that our GAAP basis results for the first quarter, included pretax restructuring cost of $97 million related to State Street Beacon including the exit of our Futures Clearing business.
Now turn to Slide 8 in the slide presentation for a summary of our operating basis results for 1Q '16. 1Q '16 results reflect softness in our fee revenue, primarily driven by lower global equity markets partially offset by strong expense control.
Operating basis EPS for 1Q '16 decreased to $0.98 a share from $1.16 in 1Q '15 and decreased from $1.21 in 4Q '15. Our first quarter results in 2015 and 2016 included the seasonal effect of deferred incentive comp for retirement eligible employees and payroll taxes.
Importantly, total expenses were approximately flat compared to the year-ago quarter. And excluding the noted seasonable retirement eligible expenses and payroll taxes, total expenses were approximately flat compared to 4Q '15. [indiscernible] capital in 1Q '16, we've cleared a common stock dividend of $0.34 a share and purchased approximately $325 million of our common stock.
Moving now to Slide 9. 1Q '16 fee revenue decreased 3.6%, while expenses were approximately flat versus a year ago. Weakness in global equity markets and elevated 1Q '15 FX revenue resulting from the Swiss financial bank actions at a time, contributed to the decrease of fee revenue relative to the year-ago quarter.
I'll now turn to Slide 11 for a review of our 1Q '16 operating business revenues. Servicing fees decreased from a year-ago quarter primarily due to the lower global equity markets and the impact of the strong U.S. dollar, partially offset by net new business. The decrease in international equity markets, particularly in emerging markets negatively impacted first quarter servicing fees. Compared to the year-ago quarter, average daily values for the Morgan Stanley emerging market index decreased 22%, while the ETF equity index was down approximately 12%.
Management fees decreased relative to a year ago, reflecting global equity markets and net outflows, partially offset by lower money market fee waivers. Foreign-exchange revenue decreased from the strong market activity in 1Q '15 to the lower volatility and volumes, nevertheless, it increased relative to 4Q '15.
Securities finance revenue increased from 1Q '15 and 4Q '15. The increase of over periods reflects increased revenue from both enhanced custody and agency lending.
Compared to the 4Q '15, processing and other revenue decreased reflecting lower equity earnings from joint ventures and lower revenues associated with tax and management investments.
Moving to Slide 12, I would note that our operating basis 1Q '16 net interest revenue benefited from the higher hedge funds rate and discipline liability pricing. Net interest revenue decreased from a year ago, primarily driven by the successful reduction in the size of our balance sheet.
Now let's turn to Slide 13 to review 1Q '16 operating basis expenses. Importantly, total operating basis expenses were well-controlled in 1Q '16 or approximately flat relative to 1Q '15, a notable accomplishment.
Compensation fee benefits were impacted by the seasonal, deferred incentive compensation for retirement eligible employees and payroll taxes. Demonstrating solid expense control, the other expense category, decreased significantly as compared to 1Q '15 and 4Q '15. Compared to 4Q '15, lower other expenses were given lower professional services fees and travel expenses as well as the settlement in the Securities and Exchange Commission recorded in the fourth quarter of 2015.
Now turning to Slide 15 to review our capital position. As you can see, our capital ratios remains strong, which is enable us to accomplish a key priority of returning capital to shareholders through dividends and common stock purchases. Compared to December 31, our common equity Tier 1 ratio increased under Basel 3 fully based in advance approach and remained approximately flat under the standardized approach. Importantly, the March 31 fully phased-in supplementary leverage ratio at the back increased 6.2%, primarily due to an increase in Tier 1 capital.
We purchased $225 million of common stock in 1Q '16 and expect to repurchase up to $390 million in 2Q '16. This will put us approximately $65 million below our gross share repurchase program of $1.83 billion. The $65 million difference represents the reduction in our 1Q '16 equity compensation for our employees relative to what we expected at the time our capital plan was approved. The net repurchase amount is, therefore, consistent with the capital plan.
Moving onto the next slide, let me briefly discuss our agreement to acquire GE Asset Management. While it remains a top priority to return capital to shareholders through common stock repurchases and dividends, we also are focused on allocating capital to hire growth and return businesses. The agreement to acquire GE Asset Management reflects this plan. The purchase price is $435 billion subject to adjustments with up to an additional $50 million tied to incremental opportunities with GE. Excluding merger integration charges, the transaction is expected to be accretive to operating basis EPS from the first 12-month period following the close of transaction and we're targeting a client asset retention lead of at least 90%. Importantly, the acquisition was significantly enhanced State Street's position in the fast-growing outsourced chief investment outsourcing market.
Moving to Slide 17. I will now provide an update to our 2016 financial outlook. Despite the pressure on global equity markets in the first quarter, we are encouraged that the environment improved in March. Importantly, compared to January and February, servicing and management fees improved in March. On expense front, we continue to expect operating basis expenses of up to 2% for full year 2016 compared to full year 2015 with variability across quarters. We also continue to expect to generate positive fee operating leverage relative to 2015. Please note my comments related to our 2016 outlook exclude any potential impact from the acquisition of GE Asset Management. Also we're on track to generate at least $100 million in estimated annual pretax net run-rate expense savings from State Street Beacon by the end of 2016.
Now as a reminder, a pressure on regulatory and compliance cost is expected to continue throughout 2016. However, we expect that growth rate to be lower than full year 2015 relative to 2014. We also expect expense growth to be affected by the volume of new business as well as continued investments.
In addition, we continue to have 2 scenarios for 2016 net interest revenue largely consistent with prior communications. The first scenario was to use market interest rates static at March 2016 levels. Under this scenario, we expect full year 2016 NIR to be in the range of approximately $2.025 billion to $2.125 billion. The second scenario assumes administered rates in the U.S. increase 25 basis points in both June and December and correspondingly, market rates to trend higher from March 2016 levels. Under this scenario, we expect full year 2016 NIR to be the range of approximately $2.1 billion to $2.2 billion. We continue to expect the 2016 operating basis tax rate to be 30% to 32%. And lastly, I would emphasize that returning capital to shareholders from share repurchase and dividends remains a priority. Our 2016 capital plan remains subject to the results of the 2016 CCAR process, including the review by the Federal Reserve Board.
In summary, although the revenue environment remains challenging as reflected in 1Q '16 results, we're encouraged that fee revenue gained momentum in March and we remain focused on prudently managing expenses in providing solutions to our clients.
Now, let me turn the call back over to Jay.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I would point to a couple of things, and I wouldn't characterize it, Ashley, as the impact on other asset bucket but there were a couple of things that probably helped us. First of all, as we've discussed before, we have a significant amount of our
componenttext: Okay. I would point to a couple of things, and I wouldn't characterize it, Ashley, as the impact on other asset bucket but there were a couple of things that probably helped us. First of all, as we've discussed before, we have a significant amount of our balance sheet that is in floating-rate assets. So that's a combination of the Central Bank deposits that we had here in the U.S. that includes the summit securities and the securities portfolio, about half of the folding rate securities are in US dollars, so that's approximately $18 billion. And then we also -- our loans tend to be also a floating-rate asset. So basically, the floating-rate in our balance sheet increased as you would expect based upon the increase in short-term market interest rates. In addition, we also were able to capture a wider spread on client repo and we also saw increased netting for repo. So those 2 things combined increased, what you see on the average rates earned and paid page, that increased significantly average rate for the assets that are in the repo securities category. And then in the other interest earning asset line that we specifically asked about, that's our Enhanced Custody asset and basically, that just reflects the market rate increase as a result of short-term rates being higher.

componenttext: Just a one more follow-up on the NII then, Mike, do you normalize some of those helpers, because if I take what you're saying about that and just think about the fact that you left without rates band unchanged, it would seem that even to get down to that high-end of that x rates spend, you talked about more of 5, 10 type of net interest income run rate. So can you just new kind of help us just walk through how much of that first quarter goes away? And then the other typical pushes and pulls in terms of any lingering yield compression versus balance sheet shrinkage we should be thinking about?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The couple of things that we expect in the static rates that -- the couple of things that we expect to put downward pressure on our NIR under our static scenario would be number one the grind in the fixed rate portion of the portfolio. So I mentione
componenttext: Sure. The couple of things that we expect in the static rates that -- the couple of things that we expect to put downward pressure on our NIR under our static scenario would be number one the grind in the fixed rate portion of the portfolio. So I mentioned that approximately $36 billion of our portfolio is forwarding rate, about half of that is in the U.S. have benefited from the short-term rate hike. About half of that is outside U.S., which obviously did not benefit from the short-term rate hike. But in the fixed rate category, which is approximately $66 billion of the portfolio, we're seeing this grind where the rates on the investments that are maturing is approximately 100 to 150 basis points higher revenue in the new fixed rate investments that we're making with the proceeds from those maturities. So that grind over the course of the year is a negative. As we talked about before, in Europe, the situation is still relatively negative in that not only our short-term interest rates negative with the ECB but in addition to that because of the quantitative ECB program over there, spreads are really keen as well. So the grind in the portfolio in Europe as well is putting downward pressure. So in static rates scenario, we would expect those to be to big drivers of the lower NIR in the next [indiscernible] of the quarters. If instead through, we get a couple of more fund hikes. We would expect them to be quite as accretive as what we saw in first quarter but obviously, we would expect it to be net-net helpful is to get a higher rate on the floating rate assets as we mentioned and in response to this question.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first, Ken, I appreciate the complement on the first quarter results, we are really pleased with that. And as we talk about at the Investor Day, we continue to look at really every single area of expenses and I think, we did a particularly good job i
componenttext: Yes, first, Ken, I appreciate the complement on the first quarter results, we are really pleased with that. And as we talk about at the Investor Day, we continue to look at really every single area of expenses and I think, we did a particularly good job in Q1 at reducing the outside consulting expenses, some of it regulatory, some of it not some of it not regulatory and reduce travel expenses significantly in Q1. But I do expect that there'll be a March up in regulatory expenses in Q2, Q3, Q4 as a result of dealing with the higher expectation. Now having said that, we will continue to look at every area of expense as Jay talked about, Project Beacon continues to be on track for the expected $100 million of savings for the full year. But again, between the regulatory cost and the net new business that we expect to be coming on board that will lead expense to service here, we thought it made sense to stick with the up to or to say, up to 2% on expense growth. And obviously, a lot of the when will also relate to the where the fee revenue is going to end up as well.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Glenn, let me start that one. Now you've seen not just this quarter but progressive quarters, good performance, outperformance in the securities lending and you're right this quarter is a combination of agency and enhanced custody. But I would say, over a
componenttext: Glenn, let me start that one. Now you've seen not just this quarter but progressive quarters, good performance, outperformance in the securities lending and you're right this quarter is a combination of agency and enhanced custody. But I would say, over a longer cycle is really been Enhanced Custody that's driven this proportionate growth, and we expect that to continue. There continues to be high demand not only hedge but in a traditional client face to use Enhanced Custody as opposed to some of the traditional means of credit, and we don't see much limitation. I'd say, most of the business growth that we're seeing quarter-to-quarter is existing clients doing more credit extension with us. So we've built out the product, I think I mentioned last quarter, we're building it out in Europe and Asia actually, we're doing that normally for all of our products. The ability to net the securities lending back against the broader portfolio makes it an attractive opposition from a capital standpoint. So net-net, we see continued demand. We don't see much in a way of capacity constraints. We think we figured out how to make this attractive from a return of capital standpoint.

componenttext: Got you. And then Jay, follow-up for you on your GE acquisition, you guys talked about pretty robust growth, I guess, in the business. But my understanding is that something like 90% or so pension assets that are, obviously, sticky there but I'm not sure how both are. Give us a sense of what organic growth has been in that business prior to your acquisition? And then maybe when you guys anticipate to see from again, the organic growth part of the business.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Happy to take that one up, Alex. As you point out, a good deal of the assets, GE assets, both pension which how the whole thing got started outsourcing the CIO function of GE's pension assets. But they've also been successful on attracting some othe
componenttext: Sure. Happy to take that one up, Alex. As you point out, a good deal of the assets, GE assets, both pension which how the whole thing got started outsourcing the CIO function of GE's pension assets. But they've also been successful on attracting some other big names in the outsource CIO market place. So I think that if you just look at that segment of the market, particularly against an environment where rates are likely to be low for an attractive period of time, we think that's a growth market. And we think by kind of an shackling GE from GE and making it part of State Street, that will be a more attractive provider of services and outsource CIO markets. So they've had some growths of their own, we've also had some growth by combining them with grow at faster rate. So that's part growth opportunity. But also core of the growth opportunities, you've head us talk before about a natural place where we play very effectively in the asset management world is in solutions, and whether it's a target fund or outsourced CIO or many other versions of solutions. And we have a little bit of a deficit in several asset classes particularly, alternatives. And so again, by taking our natural solutions capabilities and enhancing it with some of GE's very credible asset management components in the alternatives, real estate, private equity and hedge, all 3, we think we can accelerate our solutions growth. So it's really taking, I'd say, a very high-quality and stable asset management organization embedding it at State Street and 2 synergies on the revenue side and all CIO solutions segment of the market.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim. It's Mike. We did, as you suggested, we did increase the rate that we're charging for euro deposits. We did see approximately $2 billion of one off on average Q1 versus Q4. The discussions with clients are on going. I would say at this point, i
componenttext: Sure, Jim. It's Mike. We did, as you suggested, we did increase the rate that we're charging for euro deposits. We did see approximately $2 billion of one off on average Q1 versus Q4. The discussions with clients are on going. I would say at this point, it feels like a relatively well-managed situation, but it's something the we're, obviously, paying close attention to given the challenging conditions in Europe.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jim, let me just chip in on something. I would say in this call charging for negative rates, we were market leaders in that. And as I look across the landscape, we're not alone anymore. So whether it's the U.S. banks, it's the European banks, environ
componenttext: Hey, Jim, let me just chip in on something. I would say in this call charging for negative rates, we were market leaders in that. And as I look across the landscape, we're not alone anymore. So whether it's the U.S. banks, it's the European banks, environment shifted to be supportive of this activity. So I think that helps from this standpoint of being able to raise rates and maintain the deposits that we want.

componenttext: I'd like to just circle back on the repo -- on the securities repo line, the yield going from $236 million to $586 million, that's about a, looks like a $30 million sequential increase. Can you just explain that dynamic again and what would you expect the normalized rate to be in the second quarter on that?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. Well, first of all, I wouldn't focus as much on the $586 million as I would on just the overall contribution from that line item. But again, first, talk about the change in the numerator. As we took about in one of the earlier questions, we d
componenttext: Sure, Brian. Well, first of all, I wouldn't focus as much on the $586 million as I would on just the overall contribution from that line item. But again, first, talk about the change in the numerator. As we took about in one of the earlier questions, we did earn a higher spread, a wider spread on client repo in the first quarter. Basically, that's a short-term market interest rates increased. We were able to capture that in our margin. The thing that makes the average rate jump as much as it did though is that we also expanded netting in the quarter. So as a result, we actually had expanded activity of clients in the quarter, but we were able to net more of it so the average balance you see there dropped by about $0.5 billion or about 16% sequentially, but it was -- that was really from the netting. So the overall activity expanded, the spreads expanded but as a result, the average balance dropped. I wouldn't say that evidently a combination of good management and good market conditions and I would expect that market conditions will remain relatively good in the near-term. But it's something certainly we can't guarantee and it's something that we manage and monitor everyday.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on your slide, you indicated, obviously, strategic priority to be a digital leader in financial services. Could you just break apart a little bit one-liner you have there actively touching new technologies such as [indiscernible], can you give us
componenttext: And then on your slide, you indicated, obviously, strategic priority to be a digital leader in financial services. Could you just break apart a little bit one-liner you have there actively touching new technologies such as [indiscernible], can you give us a sense of what you're doing there?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Happy to do that, Betsy. This is Jay. We are watching appropriately a lot of attention, and I think, to me it's an synonymous with digitization, generally. I think if I would have put some perspective on -- put into perspective Beacon and longchain, I wou
componenttext: Happy to do that, Betsy. This is Jay. We are watching appropriately a lot of attention, and I think, to me it's an synonymous with digitization, generally. I think if I would have put some perspective on -- put into perspective Beacon and longchain, I would say that Beacon is our effort internally to digitize within the 4 walls of State Street. I think that importantly, the whole developed markets financial services infrastructure needs to be digitized, and that's going to required standardization between firms and between activities. So that's really where I se blockchain being most relevant. We have internally, within our Beacon effort, we've got I think it's 4 maybe 5 pilots going on, to use blockchain SMEs to digitize within State Street linked to other firms. So let me give you the best example and maybe the most easily explained slide example. Bank loan processing has been an activity that State Street has developed a significant share of the market, and processing of bank loan requires many intermediaries to come together in a common ledger to exchange information. So we have a pilot going on in our bank loan processing where we're using blockchain. Then we have agreements from all of the counterparties to participate in a blockchain pilot around bank loan processing. So with that would do and take an activity in process improvement and technology that do we need to do internally with State Street but it would extend it to other counterparties. So we've got several of those going on which we think could be helpful to us. I think that probably the bigger comment I would make is that we digitize our own environment, but it will require a standard across the industry and again, blockchain maybe one of those. We are participating in a group called I think it's 16 banking institutions trying to figure out what the application, the best applications are to use blockchain in order to get standard intercompany, interindustry. And so, I think, it's patchwork and absolutely do what we need to do to digitize our environment. I think the areas if we can get standards develop on how we cooperate from a digital standpoint. And I think blockchain could be, if it's not blockchain, it could be something else, one of those standards that emerge that allow the interoperability at a digital level in the whole industry. Is that kind of confuses or helps, but that's how I view it. We control and that's what we're doing with Beacon, but in order for this really to work, the industry needs to digitize. The blockchain.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, it's just a question of is it product by product? And what kind of timeframe do you see to potentially take something like the pilot that you're working on to either have a deal or no good decision with some benefits to you?
componenttext: That's helpful, it's just a question of is it product by product? And what kind of timeframe do you see to potentially take something like the pilot that you're working on to either have a deal or no good decision with some benefits to you?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. My guess is product by product at this point. And so bank loans is one of those products, one of those services. I'd be surprised if within the year, we don't know whether it would be the right answer to that issue and I think it's as with many thing
componenttext: Yes. My guess is product by product at this point. And so bank loans is one of those products, one of those services. I'd be surprised if within the year, we don't know whether it would be the right answer to that issue and I think it's as with many things, if we get a bunch of financial institutions to converge around the problem and using a new tool if successful, will go from there. I think it has a decent chance of succeeding. But it will be one of many solutions versus the several bullets.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question about product strategy, ETF, I appreciate the details earlier. In things like State Street and others have come out with fairly niche offerings recently, and the question is one of the big index in exposures already being covered including Stat
componenttext: A question about product strategy, ETF, I appreciate the details earlier. In things like State Street and others have come out with fairly niche offerings recently, and the question is one of the big index in exposures already being covered including State Street products, is that a future of ETF innovation? I know like television where there's 300 channels where everybody can see exactly what they want of that's not the whole story, how is that fitting into your overall part strength?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I appreciate the question, I might just remind you that our ETF strategy is really 2 tracks. One is to continue to buildout the distribution which we're doing and they U.S. and also Europe. And then to your point, it's enhancing the product. And I
componenttext: I think I appreciate the question, I might just remind you that our ETF strategy is really 2 tracks. One is to continue to buildout the distribution which we're doing and they U.S. and also Europe. And then to your point, it's enhancing the product. And I say a lot of the basic data strategies have been consumed in an ECF product. But then you get to the next level of customized indexes. So the she Index that we -- that I describe in my prepared comments is using a developing strategy in this case which is the first time we have self index. So we built the index, back tested it and then packaged it and the ETF. You'll see more and more of that happening, in fact, we're not the only ones doing that I think in the broad beta and ETF space, that's the theme. The other thing I would say is that I'd point to maybe the partnership we have with DoubleLine. They're taking active fixed-income strategies, they have a manager and we're packaging it in the ETF and distributing it. And I think you're going to see more and more encroachment into traditional products spaces. And I come a little short as I'm not quite sure you'll take active equity product, for instance, in rapid and in ETF. But others will take the other side of that argument. So I don't really see much limitation for investment strategies being able to being wrapped and packaged in an ETF structure and distributed to both institutions in the retail market space. So we have, I would say, that SSgA has an open platform strategy where if we can create that index in the case of she manufacturing and distributor, and we will, but if there's an interesting investment idea outside of SSgA, we're willing to discuss packaging and distributing, which we've done not just with DoubleLine but with [indiscernible] and several other firms.

componenttext: And then a question on the OCIO business in the context of asset servicing. How much synergy, revenues energy you would expect in terms of asset servicing? And if so, in what areas? Is it possible that the GE acquisition benefits from being housed from that standpoint in an organizational industry.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a good question. One of the reasons we have a 25-year-old relationship with GE is we've been the back end of the front end OCIO business that GE has run over this years. So I think that as I mentioned before, the outsourcing of the Chief Inve
componenttext: I think it's a good question. One of the reasons we have a 25-year-old relationship with GE is we've been the back end of the front end OCIO business that GE has run over this years. So I think that as I mentioned before, the outsourcing of the Chief Investment Officer function for the defined benefit plan is likely to be a growing opportunity, growth opportunity, the way you're already seeing that today. The fact that we can go in and not only offer the front office expertise of how to run these plans, how to speak the language of DB to trustees and other customer-facing pension organizations. But also be able to fully integrate the back office complete with asset service in the middle office, securities, lending, everything that is relevant here. So I see the more OCIO business we got, it should naturally bring all the back office business with it.

componenttext: Well, I would just remind you that we're still guiding to up to 2% overall expense growth year-over-year excluding the acquisition of GE asset management. So the fact that, that that's the case says to me that working to manage expenses really in aggregate and obviously, our preferred route would be to continue to build in-house capabilities, hire full-time people to manage and run these regulatory and compliance equities and rely less and less on outside consultants. And so if we continue to be successful in that area then I think that line item will likely run below last year's. But again, it really is a question of managing those priorities in aggregate as opposed to just focusing on 1 line item.

componenttext:
,
Jeff, it's Mike. I would say it is. Early days to be real specific on the actions that we'll take to ultimately meet the regulatory expectations. You saw the same information that we did in terms of the paper that lays out expectations for July 1, 2017 submission. And I think, will be on an ongoing dialogue with both the Federal Reserve as well as the FDIC over the next, at least 12 months, to make sure that we specifically understand them. So I think it's going to be a combination of all the things that you just described. There is likely to be some additional infrastructure to be built. Some of it will be additional modeling capabilities. Some of it will be a additional monitoring capabilities and also as you correctly indicated, I would expect to see additional [indiscernible] certification over time as well. But I really think it's a little bit too early to try to be specific until we have more ongoing dialogue with both groups.

componenttextpreview: I would say, Jeff, it's a pension plan. So it has a risk of restrictions. And if you look at SSJ, probably the biggest segment that they manage for our pension plans. And they do that and as long as their fulfilling their return expectation, it's unlikely
componenttext: I would say, Jeff, it's a pension plan. So it has a risk of restrictions. And if you look at SSJ, probably the biggest segment that they manage for our pension plans. And they do that and as long as their fulfilling their return expectation, it's unlikely that, that changes. And so GE has been managing this plan for long time, either we see in our business the OCIO market, very sticky assets. So I don't, frankly, view it as not a concern at all. As long as we do what we are being asked to do which we do everyday for many customers around the world and we think those assets will be with us for a long time. And the fact that we're going to combine it with our business, gives us more scale and expertise and will make us a more effective counterparty for other pension plans want to outsource that type. I view it as stable, sticky, series of assets with some capabilities we don't have today, but will allow us to grow the base.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Can you guys share with us on the new business when net asset servicing side of about $264 billion. What percentage of that was the first state super Australia win? And then second, what's the pipeline look for the second quarter.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take that one, Gerald -- Gerard. I can't give you a first super but I would tell you is that the $264 billion, a little bit unusually, 50% of that came from Asia Pacific. So we've been running more, probably 60-40 U.S. and non-U.S. For this qu
componenttext: Yes. Let me take that one, Gerald -- Gerard. I can't give you a first super but I would tell you is that the $264 billion, a little bit unusually, 50% of that came from Asia Pacific. So we've been running more, probably 60-40 U.S. and non-U.S. For this quarter, it was more 70-30, 30% being U.S., 70% non-U.S. So good progress in Asia Pacific really anchored in Australia, which I highlighted. But we've also seen some movement in Japan where we've seen the first outsourcing of investment trust fund, something we've been pursuing for a really long time. So that's the first question. The second, pipeline is quite full. I think that I said this before, but if you look at Barcelona and maybe more specifically, the asset management segment between difficulty in achieving above benchmark returns to increasing regulatory pressure, we've never seen the demand for things like outsourcing that we have on the pipe right now. And importantly, in that particular product, there's a willingness to accept standardized services. So I feel very good about the pipeline not only from a geographic standpoint, but across in particular asset managers but asset owners as well.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vivek. I'm happy to take that. We're not pleased with the margin and the asset management business, I said that before. And we do think that we are working in the strategic priorities that we laid out back in February, which are anchored in ETF solu
componenttext: Sure, Vivek. I'm happy to take that. We're not pleased with the margin and the asset management business, I said that before. And we do think that we are working in the strategic priorities that we laid out back in February, which are anchored in ETF solutions, OCIO as an additional category that we're getting the right level of focus and investing at the right amount in order to drive great top line and also create more efficiencies through the focus. And I think that if you look over an extended period of time, you would've seen we've hit a trough with regard to return and I feel like the investments that we've been making are starting to create some traction. And I look at ETFs and really, solutions has been coursed through that. In addition to some of the positioning we have in markets outside the U.S., again, I will look at those thing at cornerstone elements. So we're working on it we think were making the right investment and I think, focus is important. SSGA in some respect, does not have a lot of truer comps given what it does, and we're trying to be very good at couple of things and do them well globally and I think we're on the right track.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've got 2 views on that, Vivek, one is yes, sooner because we're making proportionally more investments in the SSGA business. And I think you will also need to the back to one of the comments we've made around the GE acquisition. As we look at our differ
componenttext: I've got 2 views on that, Vivek, one is yes, sooner because we're making proportionally more investments in the SSGA business. And I think you will also need to the back to one of the comments we've made around the GE acquisition. As we look at our different businesses within State Street and look at returns, SSgA has disproportionately high returns as a business like global exchange. As we look at investing in areas that we think have natural growth upside in addition, with the accretive to our return on equity, we're going to proportionally lean in that direction. And so I think for those reasons, I would expect to you would see SSGA improve sooner than the rest of the franchise.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the State Street Corporation's First Quarter of 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. Today's discussion is being broadcast live on State Street's website at www.statestreet.com/stockholder. This conference call is also b
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the State Street Corporation's First Quarter of 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. Today's discussion is being broadcast live on State Street's website at www.statestreet.com/stockholder. This conference call is also being recorded for replay. State Street's conference call is copyrighted and all rights are reserved. This call may not be recorded for rebroadcast or distribution in whole or in part without the express written authorization from State Street Corporation. The only authorized broadcast of this call will be housed on the State Street website.
Now I would like to introduce Anthony Ostler, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations at State Street.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Therese. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us.On our call today, our Chairman and CEO, Jay Hooley, will speak first; then Mike Bell, our CFO, will take you through our first quarter 2016 earnings slide presentation, which is available
componenttext:
Thanks, Therese. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us.
On our call today, our Chairman and CEO, Jay Hooley, will speak first; then Mike Bell, our CFO, will take you through our first quarter 2016 earnings slide presentation, which is available for download in the Investor Relations section of our website, www.statestreet.com. Afterwards, we'll be happy to take questions. [Operator Instructions]
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that today's presentation will include operating basis and other measures presented on a non-GAAP basis. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP or regulatory measures are available in the appendix to our 1Q '16 slide presentation. In addition, today's presentation will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those statements due to a variety of important factors, such as those factors referenced in our discussion today in our 1Q '16 slide presentation under the heading Forward-Looking Statements and in our SEC filings, including the Risk Factors section of our 2015 Form 10-K. Our forward-looking statements speak only as of today, and we disclaim any obligation to update them, even if our views change. As with the past couple of quarters, we have instituted a new pattern of releasing our financial results on the fourth Wednesday of the month following each quarter end. As such, we expect to hold our second quarter earnings call on Wednesday, July 27, 2016.
Now, let me turn it over to Jay.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone.Despite the challenging environment, I'm pleased with the progress we made during the quarter on the 5 strategic priorities I outlined for you at our Investor Day in February. These priorities will help us to
componenttext:
Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone.
Despite the challenging environment, I'm pleased with the progress we made during the quarter on the 5 strategic priorities I outlined for you at our Investor Day in February. These priorities will help us to transform State Street, compete in a new environment and deliver value on the short-term. As a reminder, these priorities are: one, to become a digital leader in financial services; to drive growth from our core franchise; to invest in new products that will enhance revenue and drive differentiation; increase our focus on expense management; and leverage our strong capital position to continue to return capital to shareholders.
As you can see on Slide 4 of the slide deck, we've outlined for you highlights of our progress so far this year against those 5 priorities. First, on becoming a digital leader in financial services. We are investing and becoming a digital leader in financial services through State Street Beacon. Our journey to digitize core processes will deliver an enhanced client experience and generate $550 million in annual pretax net run-rate expense savings by the end of 2020. Our clients are already beginning to see the results of our investments through faster and more consistent delivery of services, impacting our clients' operations and driving improved ranking within distribution channels. We are also actively engaged in evaluating new technologies such as Blockchain.
We remain on track to achieve State Street Beacon-related annualized run rate savings of $100 million by the end of this year. That amount will be reflected in our 2017 results. As we indicated it could be the case at our Investor Day, we did take a pretax restructuring charge of $97 million in the first quarter related to Beacon.
Second, we expect our core franchise to continue to deliver growth, given our leading positions in attractive markets. Although our first quarter fee revenues reflected challenging market environment experienced at the beginning of the year, I'm encouraged by the signs of stability in March and the strength of our pipeline across the firm. The first quarter included new asset servicing wins of approximately $264 billion, with approximately $400 billion of service commitments remaining at quarter-end to be installed from current and prior periods.
I want to highlight a win that our global services group in Asia Pacific recently finalized. In early March, we were selected to be the master custodian for Australia's third largest superannuation fund, First State Super. This new relationship will also extend into global markets and our global exchange businesses. Of note, State Street now services 4 of the 7 largest super funds in what is the high-growth sector for us in Australia. I'm also pleased to say that our asset management business had met inflows of $13 billion, with expected annualized net new revenue of $11 million during the quarter, providing the strongest quarterly net flow in annualized revenue results since the fourth quarter of 2014. Net activity was driven primarily by $7 billion of inflows into EPS and $11 billion of inflows into cash products.
Third,, we believe continuous investment in new products and solutions will enhance revenue and drive differentiation. Our recent agreement to acquire GE Asset Management supports our strategy to invest in higher growth and return businesses. GE Asset Management significantly enhanced our position in the outsourced CIO market, which is one of the faster growing segments of the asset management business. Additionally, GE Asset Management expands SSgA's alternative capabilities while enhancing our active equity and fixed income teams, which broaden the solution sets we can provide to our combined client base. Most importantly, GE Asset Management is a high quality organization with strong cultural alignment with SSgA. And this transaction is an endorsement of our ongoing and strong long-term relationship with GE. We expect this acquisition to be accretive in the first 12 months of operation.
On an ongoing basis, we evaluate products that are not meaning strategic or financial expectations. We made the decision during the quarter to exit our futures clearing business. At the beginning of the second quarter, we completed the sale of the WM/Reuters-branded foreign exchange benchmark business to Thomson Reuters. These and other ongoing return-on-capital actions are [indiscernible] improving our efficiency, strategic focus and ROE over the medium to long-term.
Innovation is a critical differentiator in the competitive ETF segment and a key focus for SSgA. Our SSgA -- our SPDR ETF business introduced 13 new funds during the quarter, including the SSgA Gender Diversity ETF. SHE is the first self indexed ETF, and its development was inspired by CalSTRS' efforts to move the needle on gender diversity in corporate America and seeks to track performance of the SSgA gender-diversity index, which comprises large -- U.S. large-cap companies with the highest levels within their sectors of gender diversity on their Boards of Directors and in their senior leadership.
Fourth, we are increasing our focus on expense management. Our results this quarter reflect our commitment to manage expenses, with first quarter operating expenses flat compared to the same period a year ago, and also fat -- flat excluding the seasonal impact of equity compensation for retirement-eligible employees and payroll taxes compared to the fourth quarter of 2015. We continue to make expense discipline core to our culture, encouraging employees to embrace an owner's mindset and identify ways we can reduce cost across the enterprise, looking at everything from travel to consultant spend.
As I noted earlier, State Street Beacon is contributing to our expense management efforts, and we are on track to generate at least $100 million in annualized pre-tax net run-rate expense savings this year from the program.
And fifth, we're leveraging our strong capital position to continue to return capital to shareholders. Our two -- our first quarter '16 common stock dividend was $0.34 per share, and we purchased approximately $325 million of our common stock. We expect to repurchase up to $390 million of our common stock in 2Q '16.
As I just reviewed for you, we will continue to focus our attention and effort in 2016 on our strategic priorities. We expect this will allow us to generate positive fee revenue growth and to achieve our objective of generating positive fee-basis operating leverage this year relative to 2015.
Two weeks ago, the Federal Reserve and FDIC released a review of our July 2015 RRP submission. Both the Federal Reserve and FDIC know that we have made improvements over our prior plans but determined that our 2015 resolution plan is not credible. While disappointed with the findings, we're committed to addressing the issues in advancing our resolution plan as our business and regulatory requirements evolve. We've had ongoing communications with the regulator and are focused on addressing all the deficiencies jointly identified by the Federal Reserve and the FDIC by October 1, 2016.
Now I'll turn the call over to Mike, who will review our financial performance for the first quarter, and then we'll both be available to take your questions.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Good morning, everyone.This morning, before I start my review of our operating basis results, I'd like to note that our GAAP basis results for the first quarter included pretax restructuring cost of $97 million related to State Street Be
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay. Good morning, everyone.
This morning, before I start my review of our operating basis results, I'd like to note that our GAAP basis results for the first quarter included pretax restructuring cost of $97 million related to State Street Beacon, including the exit of our futures clearing business.
Now turn to Slide 8 in the slide presentation for a summary of our operating basis results for 1Q '16. 1Q '16 results reflect softness in our fee revenue, primarily driven by lower global equity markets, partially offset by strong expense control.
Operating basis EPS for 1Q '16 decreased to $0.98 a share from $1.16 in 1Q '15 and decreased from $1.21 in 4Q '15. Our first quarter results in 2015 and 2016 included the seasonal effect of deferred incentive comp for retirement-eligible employees and payroll taxes.
Importantly, total expenses were approximately flat compared to the year-ago quarter. And excluding the noted seasonable -- seasonal retirement-eligible expenses and payroll taxes, total expenses were approximately flat compared to 4Q '15. Regarding capital in 1Q '16, we declared a common stock dividend of $0.34 a share and purchased approximately $325 million of our common stock.
Moving now to Slide 9. 1Q '16 fee revenue decreased 3.6%, while expenses were approximately flat versus a year ago. Weakness in global equity markets and elevated 1Q '15 FX revenue resulting from the Swiss National Bank actions at the time contributed to the decrease of fee revenue relative to the year-ago quarter.
I'll now turn to Slide 11 for a review of our 1Q '16 operating basis revenues. Servicing fees decreased from the year-ago quarter primarily due to the lower global equity markets and the impact of the stronger U.S. dollar, partially offset by net new business. The decrease in international equity markets, particularly in emerging markets, negatively impacted first quarter servicing fees. Compared to the year-ago quarter, average daily values for the Morgan Stanley emerging market index decreased 22%, while the equity index was down approximately 12%.
Management fees decreased relative to a year ago, reflecting global equity markets and net outflows, partially offset by lower money market fee waivers. Foreign-exchange revenue decreased from the strong market activity in 1Q '15 due to lower volatility and volumes. Nevertheless, it increased relative to 4Q '15.
Securities finance revenue increased from 1Q '15 and 4Q '15. The increase over both periods reflects increased revenue from both enhanced custody and agency lending.
Compared to 4Q '15, processing and other revenue decreased, reflecting lower equity earnings from joint ventures and lower revenues associated with tax-advantaged investments.
Moving to Slide 12, I would note that our operating basis 1Q '16 net interest revenue benefited from the higher Fed funds rate and disciplined liability pricing. Net interest revenue decreased from the year ago, primarily driven by the successful reduction in the size of our balance sheet.
Now let's turn to Slide 13 to review 1Q '16 operating basis expenses. Importantly, total operating basis expenses were well-controlled in 1Q '16 and were approximately flat relative to 1Q '15, a notable accomplishment.
Compensation and employee benefits were impacted by the seasonal deferred incentive compensation for retirement-eligible employees and payroll taxes. Demonstrating solid expense control, the other expense category decreased significantly as compared to both 1Q '15 and 4Q '15. Compared to 4Q '15, lower other expenses were driven by lower professional services fees and travel expenses as well as the settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission recorded in the fourth quarter of 2015.
Now turning to Slide 15 to review our capital position. As you can see, our capital ratios remains strong, which has enabled us to accomplish a key priority of returning capital to shareholders through dividends and common stock purchases. Compared to December 31, our common equity Tier 1 ratio increased under the Basel III fully phased-in advanced approach and remained approximately flat under the standardized approach. Importantly, the March 31 fully phased-in supplementary leverage ratio at the bank increased to 6.2%, primarily due to an increase in Tier 1 capital.
We repurchased $325 million of common stock in 1Q '16 and expect to repurchase up to $390 million in 2Q '16. This will put us approximately $65 million below our gross share repurchase program of $1.83 billion. The $65 million difference represents the reduction in our 1Q '16 equity compensation for our employees relative to what we expected at the time our capital plan was approved. The net repurchase amount is, therefore, consistent with the capital plan.
Moving onto the next slide, let me briefly discuss our agreement to acquire GE Asset Management. While it remains a top priority to return capital to shareholders through common stock repurchases and dividends, we also are focused on allocating capital to higher growth and return businesses. The agreement to acquire GE Asset Management reflects this plan. The purchase price is $435 million subject to adjustments, with up to an additional $50 million tied to incremental opportunities with GE. Excluding merger and integration charges, the transaction is expected to be accretive to operating basis EPS for the first 12-month period following the close of the transaction, and we're targeting a client asset retention rate of at least 90%. Importantly, the acquisition will significantly enhance State Street's position in the fast-growing outsourced chief investment officer market.
Moving to Slide 17. I'll now provide an update to our 2016 financial outlook. Despite the pressure on global equity markets in the first quarter, we are encouraged that the environment improved in March. Importantly, compared to January and February, servicing and management fees improved in March. On the expense front, we continue to expect operating basis expense growth of up to 2% for full year 2016 compared to full year 2015, with variability across quarters. We also continue to expect to generate positive fee operating leverage relative to 2015. Please note, my comments related to our 2016 outlook exclude any potential impact from the acquisition of GE Asset Management. Also we're on track to generate at least $100 million in estimated annual pretax net run-rate expense savings from State Street Beacon by the end of 2016.
Now as a reminder, upward pressure on regulatory and compliance cost is expected to continue throughout 2016. However, we expect the growth rate to be lower than full year 2015 relative to 2014. We also expect expense growth to be affected by the volume of new business as well as continued investments.
In addition, we continue to have 2 scenarios for 2016 net interest revenue, largely consistent with prior communications. The first scenario assumes market interest rates remain static at March 2016 levels. Under this scenario, we expect full year 2016 NIR to be in a range of approximately $2.025 billion to $2.125 billion. The second scenario assumes administered rates in the U.S. increase 25 basis points in both June and December and correspondingly, market rates to trend higher from March 2016 levels. Under this scenario, we expect full year 2016 NIR to be in a range of approximately $2.1 billion to $2.2 billion. We continue to expect the 2016 operating basis tax rate to be 30% to 32%. And lastly, I would emphasize that returning capital to shareholders through share repurchase and dividends remains a priority. Our 2016 capital plan remains subject to the results of the 2016 CCAR process, including the review by the Federal Reserve Board.
In summary, although the revenue environment remains challenging as reflected in 1Q '16 results, we're encouraged that fee revenue gained momentum in March, and we remain focused on prudently managing expenses and providing solutions to our clients.
Now, let me turn the call back over to Jay.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so it's still fairly early innings there. Okay. And just 2 -- and if I look at the net interest revenues this quarter and the sequential jump in NIM, what drove the increase in yields on the other asset bucket?
componenttext: Okay, so it's still fairly early innings there. Okay. And just 2 -- and if I look at the net interest revenues this quarter and the sequential jump in NIM, what drove the increase in yields on the other asset bucket?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's see. I would point to a couple of things, and I wouldn't characterize it, Ashley, as just the impact on the other asset bucket, but there were a couple of things that broadly helped us. First of all, as we've discussed before, we have a significant
componenttext: Let's see. I would point to a couple of things, and I wouldn't characterize it, Ashley, as just the impact on the other asset bucket, but there were a couple of things that broadly helped us. First of all, as we've discussed before, we have a significant amount of our balance sheet that is in floating-rate assets. So that's a combination of the Central Bank deposits that we have here in the U.S. that includes floating-rate securities in the securities portfolio, about half of the floating-rate securities are in U.S. dollars, so that's approximately $18 billion. And then we also -- our loans tend to be also a floating-rate asset. So basically, the floating-rate assets in our balance sheet increased as you would expect, based upon the increase in short-term market interest rates. In addition, we also were able to capture a wider spread on client repo, and we also saw increased netting of -- for repo. So those 2 things combined increased what you see on the average rates earned and paid page that increased significantly the average rate for the assets that are in the repo securities category. And then in the other interest earning asset line that you specifically asked about, that's our Enhanced Custody asset, and basically, that just reflects the market rate increase as a result of short-term rates being higher.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one more follow-up on the NII front then, Mike. So if you -- do you normalize for some of those helpers because if I take what you're saying about that and just think about the fact that you've left the without-rates band unchanged, it would seem tha
componenttext: Just one more follow-up on the NII front then, Mike. So if you -- do you normalize for some of those helpers because if I take what you're saying about that and just think about the fact that you've left the without-rates band unchanged, it would seem that to even to get down to that high-end of that x rate spend, you're talking about more of like a 5, 10 type of net interest income run rate. So can you just kind of help us just walk through how much of that first quarter goes away? And then the other typical pushes and pulls in terms of any lingering yield compression versus balance sheet shrinkage we should be thinking about.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, absolutely, Ken. Good morning. The couple of things that we expect in the static rate scenario, Ken, the couple of things that we expect to put downward pressure on our NIR under the static scenario would be, number one, the grind in the fixed rate
componenttext: Sure, absolutely, Ken. Good morning. The couple of things that we expect in the static rate scenario, Ken, the couple of things that we expect to put downward pressure on our NIR under the static scenario would be, number one, the grind in the fixed rate portion of the portfolio. So I mentioned that approximately $36 billion of our portfolio is floating rate. About half of that is in the U.S. that benefited from the short-term rate hike. About half of that is outside the U.S., which obviously did not benefit from the short-term rate hike. But in the fixed rate category, which is approximately $66 billion of the portfolio, we're seeing this grind where the rate on the investments that are maturing is approximately 100 to 150 basis points higher than the new fixed-rate investments that we're making with the proceeds from those maturities. So that grind over the course of the year is a negative. And as we talked about before, in Europe, the situation is still relatively negative in that not only are the short-term interest rates negative with the ECB but in addition to that, because of the quantitative ECB program over there, spreads are really teeny as well. So the grind in the portfolio in Europe as well is putting downward pressure. So in the static rate scenario, we would expect those to be the big drivers of the lower NIR in the next several quarters. If instead, through, we get a couple more dead fund hikes, we wouldn't expect them to be quite as accretive as what we saw in the first quarter, but obviously, we would expect it to be net-net helpful as we get a higher rate on the floating-rate assets that I mentioned in response to Ashley's question.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, Mike. And just a second question on expenses. Great start on the flat year-over-year, but you're also keeping to a -- up to or a 2% full year, and to your point about the compliance builds and also the volatility quarter-to-quarter, are we also imp
componenttext: Great, Mike. And just a second question on expenses. Great start on the flat year-over-year, but you're also keeping to a -- up to or a 2% full year, and to your point about the compliance builds and also the volatility quarter-to-quarter, are we also implying that expenses do have a distinct upward trail from here? Because it would seem like you're on a better trajectory. Why couldn't you do better than that 2% guidance you had given us at Investor Day?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first, Ken, I appreciate the complement on the first quarter results. We are really pleased with that. And as we talked about at the Investor Day, we continue to look at really every single area of expenses, and I think, we did a particularly good jo
componenttext: Yes, first, Ken, I appreciate the complement on the first quarter results. We are really pleased with that. And as we talked about at the Investor Day, we continue to look at really every single area of expenses, and I think, we did a particularly good job in Q1 at reducing the outside consulting expenses, some of it regulatory, some of it not regulatory. We reduced travel expenses significantly in Q1. But there -- I do expect that there'll be a march up in regulatory expenses in Q2, Q3, Q4 as a result of dealing with the higher expectations. Now having said that, we'll continue to look at every area of expense, as Jay talked about. Project Beacon continues to be on track for the expected $100 million of savings for the full year. But again, between the regulatory cost and the net new business that we expect to be coming on board that will need expense to service, we thought it made sense to stick with the up to -- or to say, up to 2% on expense growth. And obviously, a lot of where we'll end up will also relate to where the fee revenue ends up as well.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two business questions. First one's on Enhanced Custody and agency lending. You mentioned the wider spreads and -- or I should say, the growth and the higher short-term rates. But curious on just overall balance as in progress of the business. It seems to
componenttext: Two business questions. First one's on Enhanced Custody and agency lending. You mentioned the wider spreads and -- or I should say, the growth and the higher short-term rates. But curious on just overall balance as in progress of the business. It seems to be growing fast. You've talked about it in the past, but how -- what are the goals in terms of how much you want to grow it? And what risks -- or let me rephrase that, what capital charges go along with growing that business?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Glenn, let me start that one. Now you've seen not just this quarter but progressive quarters, good performance, outperformance in securities lending, and you're right, this quarter was a combination of agency and Enhanced Custody. But I would say, over a
componenttext: Glenn, let me start that one. Now you've seen not just this quarter but progressive quarters, good performance, outperformance in securities lending, and you're right, this quarter was a combination of agency and Enhanced Custody. But I would say, over a longer cycle, it's really been Enhanced Custody that's driven the disproportionate growth, and we expect that will continue. The -- there continues to be high demand in our, not only hedged, but in our traditional client base to use Enhanced Custody as opposed to some of the traditional means of credit. And we don't see much limitation. I'd say, most of the business growth that we're seeing quarter-to-quarter is existing clients doing more credit extension with us. So we've built out the product. I think I mentioned last quarter, we're building it out in Europe and Asia as we would do normally for all of our products. The ability to net the securities lending back against the broader portfolio makes it an attractive proposition from a capital standpoint. So net-net, we see continued demand. We don't see much in a way of capacity constraints. And we think we've figured out how to make this attractive from a return on capital standpoint.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: ROE, better than the overall company's ROE? I'm just curious if it's driving some -- your ever-increasing capital ratios or if that's just all regulatory earning.
componenttext: ROE, better than the overall company's ROE? I'm just curious if it's driving some -- your ever-increasing capital ratios or if that's just all regulatory earning.
