componenttext: Glenn, it's a little bit less but I would say, steadily improving over the last couple of years.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jim -- oh, excuse me, Alex Blostein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jim -- oh, excuse me, Alex Blostein.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the living will issue from a couple of weeks ago. What are you guys -- as far as the next steps go, what do you expect to do to address the issue, especially when it comes at the capital concern that came out of their statement? And do you a
componenttext: A question on the living will issue from a couple of weeks ago. What are you guys -- as far as the next steps go, what do you expect to do to address the issue, especially when it comes at the capital concern that came out of their statement? And do you anticipate this to have any impact on CCAR for you guys, whether, probably not so much in the -- on the quantitative piece but more on the qualitative?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Good morning, Alex, it's Mike. First of all, I don't view the capital piece, the capital item that was noted as a deficiency as being a significant problem for us to deal with. And I do not expect at this point in time that, that would have an impac
componenttext: Sure. Good morning, Alex, it's Mike. First of all, I don't view the capital piece, the capital item that was noted as a deficiency as being a significant problem for us to deal with. And I do not expect at this point in time that, that would have an impact on CCAR. Now obviously, the Fed will make the judgments that they'll make, but the -- I have no indication at this point that, that would have a negative impact. So really, what we're focused on now is better understanding the regulatory expectations, both for the October 1 deliverable as well as the submission next July 1. And so that's -- that more broadly is what we're focused on. And as Jay indicated in his prepared remarks, we are certainly committed to doing everything in our power to meeting their expectations.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then Jay, follow-up for you on the GE acquisition. You guys talked about pretty robust growth, I guess, in the business. But my understanding is that something like 90% or so [indiscernible] as GE pension assets that are obviously sticky ther
componenttext: Got you. And then Jay, follow-up for you on the GE acquisition. You guys talked about pretty robust growth, I guess, in the business. But my understanding is that something like 90% or so [indiscernible] as GE pension assets that are obviously sticky there, but I'm not sure how grossly [ph] those are. So give us a sense of what the organic growth has been in that business prior to your acquisition. And then maybe what you guys anticipate to see from again, the organic growth part of the business.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Happy to take that one up, Alex. The -- as you point out, a good deal of the assets are GE assets, both their pension, which is how the whole thing got started, outsourcing the CIO function of GE's pension assets. But they've also been successful on
componenttext: Sure. Happy to take that one up, Alex. The -- as you point out, a good deal of the assets are GE assets, both their pension, which is how the whole thing got started, outsourcing the CIO function of GE's pension assets. But they've also been successful on attracting some other big names in the outsourced CIO market place. So I think that if you just look at that segment of the market, particularly against an environment where rates are likely to be low for a protracted period of time, we think that's a growth market. And we think by kind of unshackling GE from GE and making it part of State Street, that will be a more attractive provider of services in the outsourced CIO market. So they've had some growth on their own, we've also had some growth. By combining it, we think we go at a faster rate. So that's -- part of -- that's core to the growth opportunity. But also core to the growth opportunities, you've heard us talk before about a natural place where we play very effectively in the asset management world is in solutions, and whether it's a target-date fund or outsourced CIO or many other versions of solutions. And we had a little bit of a deficit in several asset classes, particularly alternatives. And so again, by taking our natural solutions capabilities and enhancing it with some of GE's very credible asset management components in the alternatives, real estate, private equity and hedge, all 3, we think we can accelerate our solutions growth. So it's really taking up, I'd say, a very high-quality and stable asset management organization, embedding it at State Street and 2 synergies on the revenue side and the OCIO and solutions segments of the market.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jim Mitchell.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jim Mitchell.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe you could talk a little bit about euro deposits. It sounds like you raised the fee charge on those. Have you seen any runoff that's material? Or is it a little too early to tell, we'll see that in the second quarter? How do we think about your clien
componenttext: Maybe you could talk a little bit about euro deposits. It sounds like you raised the fee charge on those. Have you seen any runoff that's material? Or is it a little too early to tell, we'll see that in the second quarter? How do we think about your client reaction to raising rates?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim. Good morning, it's Mike. We did -- as you suggested, we did increase the rate that we're charging for euro deposits. We did see approximately $2 billion of run-off on average Q1 versus Q4. The discussions with clients are on going. I would say
componenttext: Sure, Jim. Good morning, it's Mike. We did -- as you suggested, we did increase the rate that we're charging for euro deposits. We did see approximately $2 billion of run-off on average Q1 versus Q4. The discussions with clients are on going. I would say at this point, it feels like a relatively well-managed situation, but it's something that we're, obviously, paying close attention to, given the challenging conditions in Europe.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jim, let me just chip in something. The -- I would say on this whole charging for negative rates, we were market leaders in that. And as I look across the landscape, we're not alone anymore. So whether it's the U.S. banks, the European banks, the env
componenttext: Hey, Jim, let me just chip in something. The -- I would say on this whole charging for negative rates, we were market leaders in that. And as I look across the landscape, we're not alone anymore. So whether it's the U.S. banks, the European banks, the environment has shifted to be supportive of this activity. So I think that helps from the standpoint of being able to raise rates and retain the deposits that we want.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And so it seems like deposits have held in a little bit better than maybe you've expected. Is that part of the upside we see in NII this quarter relative to your full year forecast?
componenttext: Right. And so it seems like deposits have held in a little bit better than maybe you've expected. Is that part of the upside we see in NII this quarter relative to your full year forecast?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I would characterize it as they're pretty much tracking with what we expected.
componenttext: Jim, I would characterize it as they're pretty much tracking with what we expected.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just ask one on the Tier 1 capital of the bank, it seems like you downstream-ed some capital there. Is that true? How did that -- how was that accomplished to boost the Tier 1 on the SLR bank?
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just ask one on the Tier 1 capital of the bank, it seems like you downstream-ed some capital there. Is that true? How did that -- how was that accomplished to boost the Tier 1 on the SLR bank?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, in terms of just administratively how we did it, we basically just routine-d some earnings at the bank as opposed to dividend-ing that from the bank to the hold co. But as we talked about in the past, Jim, we do recognize that we've got some f
componenttext: Sure. Well, in terms of just administratively how we did it, we basically just routine-d some earnings at the bank as opposed to dividend-ing that from the bank to the hold co. But as we talked about in the past, Jim, we do recognize that we've got some flexibility in terms of what assets we hold at the hold co versus what we have at the bank. So this was really normal management in line with our plan to be sure that we were above 6% in time for 1 1 18. Obviously, the fact that the balance sheet got smaller as well was also helpful in that regard.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brian Bedell.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brian Bedell.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like just to circle back on the securities repo line, the yield going from $236 million to $586 million, that's about a -- looks like around a $30 million sequential increase. Can you just explain that dynamic again and what would you expect the norma
componenttext: I'd like just to circle back on the securities repo line, the yield going from $236 million to $586 million, that's about a -- looks like around a $30 million sequential increase. Can you just explain that dynamic again and what would you expect the normalized rate to be in the second quarter on that?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. Well, first of all, I wouldn't focus as much on the $586 million as I would on just the overall contribution from that line item. But again, first, talk about the change in the numerator. As we talked about in one of the earlier questions, we
componenttext: Sure, Brian. Well, first of all, I wouldn't focus as much on the $586 million as I would on just the overall contribution from that line item. But again, first, talk about the change in the numerator. As we talked about in one of the earlier questions, we did earn a higher spread, a wider spread on client repo in the first quarter. Basically, as short-term market interest rates increased, we were able to capture that in our margin. The thing that makes the average rate jump as much as it did, though, is that we also expanded netting in the quarter. So as a result, we actually had expanded activity for clients in the quarter, but we were able to net more of it, so the average balance you see there dropped by about $0.5 billion or about 16% sequentially, but it was -- that was really from the netting. So the overall activity expanded, the spreads expanded, but the -- but as a result, the average balance then dropped. I wouldn't say that -- I think it was a combination of good management and good market conditions, and I would expect that market conditions will remain relatively good in the near-term. But it's something certainly we can't guarantee, and it's something that we manage and monitor everyday.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] that $30 million you would view as somewhat -- or the $30 million increase you would view as somewhat sustainable? Or would you see that revert back somewhat [indiscernible]?
componenttext: [indiscernible] that $30 million you would view as somewhat -- or the $30 million increase you would view as somewhat sustainable? Or would you see that revert back somewhat [indiscernible]?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that, again, time will tell, Brian. I don't have a perfect crystal ball. But I would expect that perhaps the majority of the sequential increase in those spreads should be sustained over the next couple of quarters. But again, it will be dependent
componenttext: I think that, again, time will tell, Brian. I don't have a perfect crystal ball. But I would expect that perhaps the majority of the sequential increase in those spreads should be sustained over the next couple of quarters. But again, it will be dependent upon market conditions.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. And then maybe, Jay, if you'd want to comment a little bit about the typical dividend arbitrage season in Europe. I know there's been some discussion of curtailing that. Do you -- are you seeing the same type of activity that you typically see in securities lending and FX trading coming into the second quarter? Or do you expect that to be a little bit constrained?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, the -- as you point out, second quarter is a seasonal peak for us with regard to the dividend activities. We spent a lot of attention on that over the last couple of years. So we probably see some slight diminishment from what we've seen in the pas
componenttext: Brian, the -- as you point out, second quarter is a seasonal peak for us with regard to the dividend activities. We spent a lot of attention on that over the last couple of years. So we probably see some slight diminishment from what we've seen in the past. I don't think it's material but probably not quite at the peak it's been in past years because of all the attention that trade has received.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Betsy Graseck.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Betsy Graseck.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to get on 2 things. One was on the Beacon project, do you indicated the restructuring charge of $97 million this quarter, obviously, a net savings this quarter of $7 million. I know you're investing $500 million -- you're investing $400 mill
componenttext: I just wanted to get on 2 things. One was on the Beacon project, do you indicated the restructuring charge of $97 million this quarter, obviously, a net savings this quarter of $7 million. I know you're investing $500 million -- you're investing $400 million to get a $500 million benefit over 5 years, but could you give us a sense as to how we should think about the investment and the saves as we go through the rest of this year? Because I thought it was front-end loaded, so I just wanted to make sure I have the numbers right there.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Betsy, it's Mike. I do expect that both the benefits as well as the investments that we're making in Project Beacon will both steadily increase over the course of 2016. I do expect that the net benefit will increase each of those 3 quarters. On the
componenttext: Sure, Betsy, it's Mike. I do expect that both the benefits as well as the investments that we're making in Project Beacon will both steadily increase over the course of 2016. I do expect that the net benefit will increase each of those 3 quarters. On the other hand, as I mentioned earlier, I also do expect to see some upward pressure on regulatory costs. So again, that's several moving parts, but I would think in Beacon, in particular, as both investments continue to increase and savings continuing to increase.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And all of the $97 million in investment was largely in severance? And I'm assuming that's the -- kind of below-the-line number. There -- you're not anticipating any investments in the Beacon project to be in operating expenses, are you? Or do I have that
componenttext: And all of the $97 million in investment was largely in severance? And I'm assuming that's the -- kind of below-the-line number. There -- you're not anticipating any investments in the Beacon project to be in operating expenses, are you? Or do I have that wrong?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are, Betsy. In fact, we did see investments in that area, in operating expenses that was both in compensation but it's also in the information systems outline. And again, I would expect to see additional spending in the information systems line ov
componenttext: Yes, we are, Betsy. In fact, we did see investments in that area, in operating expenses that was both in compensation but it's also in the information systems outline. And again, I would expect to see additional spending in the information systems line over the course of 2016.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on your slide, you indicated, obviously, the strategic priority to be a digital leader in financial services. Could you just break apart a little bit the one-liner you have there, "Actively testing new technologies, such as Blockchain." Could you
componenttext: And then on your slide, you indicated, obviously, the strategic priority to be a digital leader in financial services. Could you just break apart a little bit the one-liner you have there, "Actively testing new technologies, such as Blockchain." Could you give us a sense as to what you're doing there?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Happy to do that, Betsy. This is Jay. The -- Blockchain has received appropriately a lot of attention, and I think it's, to me, it's synonymous with digitization, generally. I think if I would have put some perspective on -- put into perspective Beacon an
componenttext: Happy to do that, Betsy. This is Jay. The -- Blockchain has received appropriately a lot of attention, and I think it's, to me, it's synonymous with digitization, generally. I think if I would have put some perspective on -- put into perspective Beacon and Blockchain, I would say that Beacon is our effort internally to digitize within the 4 walls of State Street. I think that importantly, the whole developed markets financial services infrastructure needs to be digitized, and that's going to require standardization between firms and between activities. So that's really where I see Blockchain being most relevant. We have internally, within our Beacon effort, we've got I think it's 4 maybe 5 pilots going on, to use Blockchain SMEs to digitize within State Street linked to other firms. So let me give you the best example and maybe the most easily explained example. Bank loan processing has been an activity that State Street has developed a significant share of the market, and processing a bank loan requires many intermediaries to come together in a common ledger to exchange information. So we have a pilot going on in our bank loan processing where we're using Blockchain. And we've got agreement from all of the counter-parties to participate in a Blockchain pilot around bank loan processing. So what that would do is take an activity where there's process improvements and technology that do we need to do internally within State Street, but it would extend it to other counter-parties. So we've got several of those going on which we think could be helpful to us. I think that probably the bigger comment I would make is that we'll digitize our own environment, but it will require standards across the industry and again, Blockchain may be one of those. We're participating in a group called R3. I think there's up to 16 banking institutions that are trying to figure out what the application -- what the best applications are to use Blockchain in order to create standards intercompany, interindustry. And so, I think it's -- we're going to absolutely do what we need to do to digitize our environment. I think the home run here is, if we can get some standards developed around how we will inter-operate from a digital standpoint. And I think Blockchain could be, if it's not Blockchain, it will be something else, one of those standards that emerge that allow the interoperability at a digital level in the whole industry. Is that -- I don't know if that confuses or helps, but that's how I view it. We can control, we control. That's what we're doing with Beacon. But in order for this really to work, the industry needs to digitize Blockchain [indiscernible].

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. It's just a question of, is it product by product? And what kind of timeframe do you see to potentially take something like the pilot that you're working on to either have a go or no go decision with some benefits to you?
componenttext: That's helpful. It's just a question of, is it product by product? And what kind of timeframe do you see to potentially take something like the pilot that you're working on to either have a go or no go decision with some benefits to you?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. My guess it's product by product at this point. And so, bank loans is one of those products, one of those services. I'd be surprised if within a year, we don't know whether it would be the right answer to that issue, and I think it's, as with many th
componenttext: Yes. My guess it's product by product at this point. And so, bank loans is one of those products, one of those services. I'd be surprised if within a year, we don't know whether it would be the right answer to that issue, and I think it's, as with many things, if we get a bunch of financial institutions to converge around a problem and use a new tool, if successful, it will grow from there. I think it's got a decent chance of succeeding. But it will be one of many solutions versus the silver bullet.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Adam Beatty.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Adam Beatty.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question about product strategy and ETFs. I appreciate the details earlier. It seems like State Street and others have come out with some fairly niche offerings recently. And the question is, with a lot of the big indexes and exposures already being cov
componenttext: A question about product strategy and ETFs. I appreciate the details earlier. It seems like State Street and others have come out with some fairly niche offerings recently. And the question is, with a lot of the big indexes and exposures already being covered including licensed State Street products, is that the future of ETF innovation? I know, like television where there's 300 channels so everybody can see exactly what they want. Or if that's not the whole story, how does that fit into your overall product strategy?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think -- I appreciate the question. And I might just remind you that our ETF strategy is really 2 tracks. One is to continue to buildout the distribution, which we're doing in the U.S. and also Europe. And then to your point, it's enhancing the pro
componenttext: Yes. I think -- I appreciate the question. And I might just remind you that our ETF strategy is really 2 tracks. One is to continue to buildout the distribution, which we're doing in the U.S. and also Europe. And then to your point, it's enhancing the product. And I'd say a lot of the basic beta strategies have been consumed in an ETF product. But then you get to the next level of customized indexes. So the SHE Index that we -- that I described in my prepared comments is using a -- is developing a strategy in developed -- in this case, this is the first time we have self-indexed. So we built the index, back tested it and then packaged it in an ETF. You'll see more and more of that happening. In fact, we're not the only ones doing that, I think. In the broad beta and ETF space, that's a theme. The other thing I would say is that I'd point to maybe the partnership we have with DoubleLine, where -- they're taking active fixed-income strategies. They're the manager, we're packaging it in the ETF and distributing it. And I think you're going to see more and more encroachment into traditional product spaces. And I come a little short because I'm not quite sold yet that you'll take active equity product, for instance, in wrap it in an ETF. But others would take the other side of that argument. So I don't really see much limitation for investment strategies being able to be wrapped and packaged in an ETF structure and distributed to both institutions in the retail market space. So we have -- I would say, that SSgA has deployed kind of an open platform strategy, where if we can create the index in the case of SHE, manufacture and distribute, and we will, but if there's an interesting investment idea outside of SSgA, we're willing to discuss packaging and distributing, which we've done, not just with DoubleLine, but with Nuveen, MFS and several other firms. Hopefully that helps.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does. And then a question on the OCIO business in the context of asset servicing. How much synergy, revenue energy would you expect in terms of asset servicing? And if so, in what areas? Is it possible that the GE acquisition benefits from being h
componenttext: Yes, it does. And then a question on the OCIO business in the context of asset servicing. How much synergy, revenue energy would you expect in terms of asset servicing? And if so, in what areas? Is it possible that the GE acquisition benefits from being housed from that standpoint in an organization like State Street?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a stewed question in that one of the reasons we have a 25-year-old relationship with GE is, we've been the back end of the front end OCIO business that GE has run over these years. So I think that, as I mentioned before, the outsourcing
componenttext: Yes. I think it's a stewed question in that one of the reasons we have a 25-year-old relationship with GE is, we've been the back end of the front end OCIO business that GE has run over these years. So I think that, as I mentioned before, the outsourcing of the Chief Investment Officer function for the defined benefit plans is likely to be a growing opportunity, growth opportunity. You're already seeing it today. The fact that we can go in and not only offer the front office expertise of how to run these plans, how to speak the language of DB to trustees and other customer-facing pension organizations. But also be able to fully integrate the back office complete with asset servicing, middle office, securities, lending, everything that goes with it is all relevant here. So I see the more OCIO business we get, it should naturally bring all the middle and back office business with it.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brennan Hawken with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brennan Hawken with UBS.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 1 quick follow-up at this point. The decline in other expenses, I think, the implication was that you had some benefit here. I think you weighed out the consulting expenses coming down but the reason why the guide didn't go up is because you've got s
componenttext: Just 1 quick follow-up at this point. The decline in other expenses, I think, the implication was that you had some benefit here. I think you weighed out the consulting expenses coming down but the reason why the guide didn't go up is because you've got some upward pressure pending from potential living will spend and such. Am I paraphrasing that correctly? Am I reading through your comments, right? Or should you -- can you clarify, please?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brennan, it's Mike. I think that's -- those are fair comments, but I wouldn't limit the upward regulatory cost pressure to just the living wills. I think it's broader than that. But other than that, your comment is very fair.
componenttext: Brennan, it's Mike. I think that's -- those are fair comments, but I wouldn't limit the upward regulatory cost pressure to just the living wills. I think it's broader than that. But other than that, your comment is very fair.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then is there a way to unpack the other expense result here that was -- it was better than expected in how much independently, you think, might be sustainable beyond then the pending upward pressure from here? Is there a way to think about that
componenttext: Okay. And then is there a way to unpack the other expense result here that was -- it was better than expected in how much independently, you think, might be sustainable beyond then the pending upward pressure from here? Is there a way to think about that separately?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just remind you that we're still guiding to up to 2% overall expense growth year-over-year, excluding the acquisition of GE Asset Management. So the fact that, that's the case says to me that we're going to manage expenses really in aggregat
componenttext: Well, I would just remind you that we're still guiding to up to 2% overall expense growth year-over-year, excluding the acquisition of GE Asset Management. So the fact that, that's the case says to me that we're going to manage expenses really in aggregate and obviously, our preferred route would be to continue to build in-house capabilities, hire full-time people to manage and run these regulatory and compliance activities and rely less and less on outside consultants. And so if we continue to be successful in that area, then I think that line item will likely run below last year's. But again, it really is a question of managing those priorities in aggregate as opposed to just focusing on one line item.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan. Your next question comes from Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan. Your next question comes from Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the GE Asset Management deal. I know you gave guidance as to what you expect the accretion to be for 1 year, and also you want to retain 90% with regards to the AUM. But -- so are we to assume that the 1 year is just because that's when
componenttext: Quick question on the GE Asset Management deal. I know you gave guidance as to what you expect the accretion to be for 1 year, and also you want to retain 90% with regards to the AUM. But -- so are we to assume that the 1 year is just because that's when the lockup period is for those assets? Or was there a longer lockup on the assets being acquired?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- Brian, I wouldn't relate the two. Basically, we were focused on the first 12 months because we wanted to give you a time period at which we expect this to be accretive to EPS. And so that really is irrespective of any kind of lockup period with
componenttext: Well, I -- Brian, I wouldn't relate the two. Basically, we were focused on the first 12 months because we wanted to give you a time period at which we expect this to be accretive to EPS. And so that really is irrespective of any kind of lockup period with the GE plan.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'd add, Brian, that our expectation is that the 90% plus business that we retain will have a long life to it.
componenttext: And I'd add, Brian, that our expectation is that the 90% plus business that we retain will have a long life to it.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, asked differently, when does the lockup period end?
componenttext: So I guess, asked differently, when does the lockup period end?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: There is not a contractual lockup period. I -- basically, we're confident that we can continue to meet the GE pension plans needs, and that's what we'll be focused on.
componenttext: There is not a contractual lockup period. I -- basically, we're confident that we can continue to meet the GE pension plans needs, and that's what we'll be focused on.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just a second question. What's the impact on the revenues from exit of the futures clearing business? Is there -- I guess, what's the impact on the pretax margin as well?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Brian, the FCM business earned $9 million in fees in full year 2015, and the expenses were greater than that but were part of the overall savings that I talked about earlier in terms of Beacon. So I wouldn't be more specific at this point.
componenttext: Sure. So Brian, the FCM business earned $9 million in fees in full year 2015, and the expenses were greater than that but were part of the overall savings that I talked about earlier in terms of Beacon. So I wouldn't be more specific at this point.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Geoffrey Elliott with from Autonomous Research.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: On the revolution plan, could you talk about what you need to do there? And how much of that is simply around changing the plan versus how much is around making changes in the way business is structured [indiscernible] liquidities that you hold, how capital is allocated between the different entities and so on?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jeff, it's Mike. I would say it is early days to be real specific on the actions that we'll take to ultimately meet the regulatory expectations. You saw the same information that we did in terms of the paper that lays out expectations for 2000 -- the J
componenttext: So Jeff, it's Mike. I would say it is early days to be real specific on the actions that we'll take to ultimately meet the regulatory expectations. You saw the same information that we did in terms of the paper that lays out expectations for 2000 -- the July 1, 2017 submission. And I think, we'll be in ongoing dialogue with both the Federal Reserve as well as the FDIC over the next, at least, 12 months to make sure that we specifically understand them. So I think it's going to be a combination of all the things that you just described. There is likely to be some additional infrastructure to be built. Some of it will be additional modeling capabilities. Some of it will be additional monitoring capabilities, and also as you correctly indicated, I would expect to see additional legal entity simplification over time as well. But I -- it -- I really think it's a little bit too early to try to be specific until we have more ongoing dialogue with both groups.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just to follow-up on the previous question, on there not being a contractual lockup on the GE Asset Management assets. Why not -- I would have thought that when you're acquiring a manager and the vast majority of the assets are in-house, that wou
componenttext: And then just to follow-up on the previous question, on there not being a contractual lockup on the GE Asset Management assets. Why not -- I would have thought that when you're acquiring a manager and the vast majority of the assets are in-house, that would be absolutely critical to making sure you don't just get the 1 year accretion that the accretion 3, 4, 5, 10 years out?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, Jeff, it's a pension plan. So it has a risk of restrictions. If you look at SSJ, well, probably the biggest segment that they managed for our pension plans. And they do that and as long as their fulfilling their return expectations, it's unli
componenttext: I would say, Jeff, it's a pension plan. So it has a risk of restrictions. If you look at SSJ, well, probably the biggest segment that they managed for our pension plans. And they do that and as long as their fulfilling their return expectations, it's unlikely that, that changes. And so GE's been managing this plan for a long time. These are, we see in our business, the OCIO market, very sticky assets. So I don't, frankly, view it as not a concern at all. As long as we do what we're being asked to do, which we do everyday for many customers around the world, then we think these assets will be with us for a long time. And the fact that we're going to combine it with our business, gives us more scale and expertise and will make us a more attractive counter-party for other pension plans that want to outsource that. I view it as a stable, sticky series of assets with some capabilities we don't have today that will allow us to grow the base.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Gerard Cassidy with RBC.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you guys share with us on the new business wins on the net asset servicing side of about $264 billion, what percentage of that was the First State Super Australia win? And then second, what's the pipeline look for the second quarter.
componenttext: Can you guys share with us on the new business wins on the net asset servicing side of about $264 billion, what percentage of that was the First State Super Australia win? And then second, what's the pipeline look for the second quarter.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me take that one, Gerald -- Gerard. I can't give you a First State Super, but what I would tell you is that the $264 billion, a little bit unusually, 50% of that came from Asia Pacific. So we've been running more, probably 60-40 U.S., non-U.S. Fo
componenttext: Yes. Let me take that one, Gerald -- Gerard. I can't give you a First State Super, but what I would tell you is that the $264 billion, a little bit unusually, 50% of that came from Asia Pacific. So we've been running more, probably 60-40 U.S., non-U.S. For this quarter, it was more 70-30, 30% being U.S., 70% non-U.S. So good progress in Asia Pacific really anchored in not only Australia, which I highlighted, but that we've also seen some movement in Japan, where we've seen the first outsourcing of investment trust funds, something we've been pursuing for a long time. So that's the first question. The second, pipelines are quite full. I think that -- I've said this before, but if you look at the asset owner and maybe and more specifically, the asset management segment between difficulty in achieving above benchmark returns to increasing regulatory pressure, we've never seen the demand for things like middle office outsourcing that we have on our plate right now. And importantly, in that particular product, there's a willingness to accept standardized services. So I feel very good about the pipeline, not only from a geographic standpoint, but across -- in particular asset managers but asset service -- asset owners as well.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe, Mike, when we look at your average balance sheet that you gave us in the supplement on Page 11, I noticed that the interest-bearing deposits in the United States, the yield on that, or the cost, I should say, to you guys jumped from 23 bas
componenttext: And then maybe, Mike, when we look at your average balance sheet that you gave us in the supplement on Page 11, I noticed that the interest-bearing deposits in the United States, the yield on that, or the cost, I should say, to you guys jumped from 23 basis points to 40 basis points. And that -- it's kind of bit -- quite a bit different than some of your peers. What caused it to jump up as -- that much?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gerard. First of all, the main driver in that category is actually the cost of our wholesale CDs. So we have approximately $15 billion on average of wholesale CD balances in Q1, and those moved with LIBOR rates. And so that's the driver of the seque
componenttext: Sure, Gerard. First of all, the main driver in that category is actually the cost of our wholesale CDs. So we have approximately $15 billion on average of wholesale CD balances in Q1, and those moved with LIBOR rates. And so that's the driver of the sequential increase there. If we strip those out and just looked at the interest-bearing DDA, that was pretty close to flat sequentially. So it's really the wholesale CDs.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the CDs as a percentage of the total that you just gave us, is that consistent with those prior periods? Or is it a greater percentage today than it was on those prior periods?
componenttext: And the CDs as a percentage of the total that you just gave us, is that consistent with those prior periods? Or is it a greater percentage today than it was on those prior periods?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably a slightly smaller percentage today at $15 billion. We use the wholesale CDs as a management tool around liquidity, and those balances were actually a little bit higher in 2015. I remember the rates were lower because LIBOR was lower in 2015
componenttext: It's probably a slightly smaller percentage today at $15 billion. We use the wholesale CDs as a management tool around liquidity, and those balances were actually a little bit higher in 2015. I remember the rates were lower because LIBOR was lower in 2015 than what it is in Q1 '16.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Vivek Juneja with JPMorgan.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. Firstly, Mike, just following up on the question you were talking about on the repo market. You said majority of the increase in spreads can be sustained in the next couple of quarters. Can you give us a little more color on what's goi
componenttext: A couple of things. Firstly, Mike, just following up on the question you were talking about on the repo market. You said majority of the increase in spreads can be sustained in the next couple of quarters. Can you give us a little more color on what's going on in that market? Structurally, that's causing this widening in spreads, and that will sustain it?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vivek. I mean, really, it's a combination of the fact that short-term interest rates have, obviously, gone up with the Fed fund hike, and it's also just a function of supply and demand. And so we'll monitor those conditions carefully, but I see noth
componenttext: Sure, Vivek. I mean, really, it's a combination of the fact that short-term interest rates have, obviously, gone up with the Fed fund hike, and it's also just a function of supply and demand. And so we'll monitor those conditions carefully, but I see nothing that would suggest that, that's going to evaporate here in Q2. So again, it's something that we'll pay close attention to.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just shifting gears, Jay. From what I could see, your asset management business, if I look at the operating margin in the fourth quarter was 13%, and if I look at full year asset management, margin was 19 and change. 13% for the fourth quarter and 1
componenttext: Okay. Just shifting gears, Jay. From what I could see, your asset management business, if I look at the operating margin in the fourth quarter was 13%, and if I look at full year asset management, margin was 19 and change. 13% for the fourth quarter and 19 and change, it's a really low margin compared to peers. Can you talk a little bit about specifically that business, what you can do to [indiscernible] in moving [indiscernible], things like EPS, what you can do to accelerate the operating margin improvement and why so far behind peers?

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vivek. I'm happy to take that. We're not pleased with the margin in the SSJ business. I think I said that before. And we do think by reorienting around the strategic priorities that we laid out back in February, which are anchored in ETF solutions,
componenttext: Sure, Vivek. I'm happy to take that. We're not pleased with the margin in the SSJ business. I think I said that before. And we do think by reorienting around the strategic priorities that we laid out back in February, which are anchored in ETF solutions, OCIO as an additional category, that we're getting the right level of focus and investing at the right amount in order to drive really top line and also create more efficiencies through the focus. And I think that if you look over an extended period of time, you would've seen we've hit a trough with regard to returns, and I feel like the investments that we've been making are starting to create some traction. And I look at ETFs and really, solutions as being cornerstone of that. In addition to some of the positioning we have in markets outside the U.S., again, I would look to those same two cornerstone elements. So we're working on it, we think we're making the right investments. I think, focus is important. SSgA, in some respects, does not have a lot of truer comps, given what it does, and we're trying to be very good at a couple of things and do them well globally, and I think we're on the right track.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you think it will be sooner in SSgA in terms of -- you've given us targets for all overall comp [indiscernible] operating margin improvement. Do you SSgA doing the same timeframe or sooner, Jay, compared to the servicing business? [indiscernible]
componenttext: And do you think it will be sooner in SSgA in terms of -- you've given us targets for all overall comp [indiscernible] operating margin improvement. Do you SSgA doing the same timeframe or sooner, Jay, compared to the servicing business? [indiscernible]

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've got 2 views on that, Vivek. One is, yes, sooner because we're making proportionately more investments in the SSgA business. And I think you will also need to come back to one of the comments we've made around the GE acquisition. As we look at our dif
componenttext: I've got 2 views on that, Vivek. One is, yes, sooner because we're making proportionately more investments in the SSgA business. And I think you will also need to come back to one of the comments we've made around the GE acquisition. As we look at our different businesses within State Street and look at returns, SSgA has a disproportionately higher return as does a business like global exchange. So as we look at investing in areas that we think have natural growth upside and in addition, would be accretive to our return on equity, we're going to proportionately lean in that direction. And so I think for those reasons, I would expect that you would see SSgA improve sooner than the rest of the franchise.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the State Street Corporation's First Quarter of 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. Today's discussion is being broadcast live on State Street's website at www.statestreet.com/stockholder. This conference call is also b
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the State Street Corporation's First Quarter of 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. Today's discussion is being broadcast live on State Street's website at www.statestreet.com/stockholder. This conference call is also being recorded for replay. State Street's conference call is copyrighted and all rights are reserved. This call may not be recorded for rebroadcast or distribution in whole or in part without the express written authorization from State Street Corporation. The only authorized broadcast of this call will be housed on the State Street website.
Now I would like to introduce Anthony Ostler, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations at State Street.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Therese. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us.On our call today, our Chairman and CEO, Jay Hooley, will speak first; then Mike Bell, our CFO, will take you through our first quarter 2016 earnings slide presentation, which is available
componenttext:
Thanks, Therese. Good morning, and thank you all for joining us.
On our call today, our Chairman and CEO, Jay Hooley, will speak first; then Mike Bell, our CFO, will take you through our first quarter 2016 earnings slide presentation, which is available for download in the Investor Relations section of our website, www.statestreet.com. Afterwards, we'll be happy to take questions. [Operator Instructions]
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that today's presentation will include operating basis and other measures presented on a non-GAAP basis. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP or regulatory measures are available in the appendix to our 1Q '16 slide presentation. In addition, today's presentation will contain forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those statements due to a variety of important factors, such as those factors referenced in our discussion today in our 1Q '16 slide presentation under the heading Forward-Looking Statements and in our SEC filings, including the Risk Factors section of our 2015 Form 10-K. Our forward-looking statements speak only as of today, and we disclaim any obligation to update them, even if our views change. As with the past couple of quarters, we have instituted a new pattern of releasing our financial results on the fourth Wednesday of the month following each quarter end. As such, we expect to hold our second quarter earnings call on Wednesday, July 27, 2016.
Now, let me turn it over to Jay.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone.Despite the challenging environment, I'm pleased with the progress we made during the quarter on the 5 strategic priorities I outlined for you at our Investor Day in February. These priorities will help us to
componenttext:
Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone.
Despite the challenging environment, I'm pleased with the progress we made during the quarter on the 5 strategic priorities I outlined for you at our Investor Day in February. These priorities will help us to transform State Street, compete in a new environment and deliver value on the short-term. As a reminder, these priorities are: one, to become a digital leader in financial services; to drive growth from our core franchise; to invest in new products that will enhance revenue and drive differentiation; increase our focus on expense management; and leverage our strong capital position to continue to return capital to shareholders.
As you can see on Slide 4 of the slide deck, we've outlined for you highlights of our progress so far this year against those 5 priorities. First, on becoming a digital leader in financial services. We are investing and becoming a digital leader in financial services through State Street Beacon. Our journey to digitize core processes will deliver an enhanced client experience and generate $550 million in annual pretax net run-rate expense savings by the end of 2020. Our clients are already beginning to see the results of our investments through faster and more consistent delivery of services, impacting our clients' operations and driving improved ranking within distribution channels. We are also actively engaged in evaluating new technologies such as Blockchain.
We remain on track to achieve State Street Beacon-related annualized run rate savings of $100 million by the end of this year. That amount will be reflected in our 2017 results. As we indicated it could be the case at our Investor Day, we did take a pretax restructuring charge of $97 million in the first quarter related to Beacon.
Second, we expect our core franchise to continue to deliver growth, given our leading positions in attractive markets. Although our first quarter fee revenues reflected challenging market environment experienced at the beginning of the year, I'm encouraged by the signs of stability in March and the strength of our pipeline across the firm. The first quarter included new asset servicing wins of approximately $264 billion, with approximately $400 billion of service commitments remaining at quarter-end to be installed from current and prior periods.
I want to highlight a win that our global services group in Asia Pacific recently finalized. In early March, we were selected to be the master custodian for Australia's third largest superannuation fund, First State Super. This new relationship will also extend into global markets and our global exchange businesses. Of note, State Street now services 4 of the 7 largest super funds in what is the high-growth sector for us in Australia. I'm also pleased to say that our asset management business had net inflows of $13 billion, with expected annualized net new revenue of $11 million during the quarter, providing the strongest quarterly net flow in annualized revenue results since the fourth quarter of 2014. Net activity was driven primarily by $7 billion of inflows into EPS and $11 billion of inflows into cash products.
Third,, we believe continuous investment in new products and solutions will enhance revenue and drive differentiation. Our recent agreement to acquire GE Asset Management supports our strategy to invest in higher growth and return businesses. GE Asset Management significantly enhanced our position in the outsourced CIO market, which is one of the faster growing segments of the asset management business. Additionally, GE Asset Management expands SSgA's alternative capabilities while enhancing our active equity and fixed income teams, which broaden the solution sets we can provide to our combined client base. Most importantly, GE Asset Management is a high quality organization with strong cultural alignment with SSgA. And this transaction is an endorsement of our ongoing and strong long-term relationship with GE. We expect this acquisition to be accretive in the first 12 months of operation.
On an ongoing basis, we evaluate products that are not meaning strategic or financial expectations. We made the decision during the quarter to exit our futures clearing business. At the beginning of the second quarter, we completed the sale of the WM/Reuters-branded foreign exchange benchmark business to Thomson Reuters. These and other ongoing return-on-capital actions are [indiscernible] improving our efficiency, strategic focus and ROE over the medium to long-term.
Innovation is a critical differentiator in the competitive ETF segment and a key focus for SSgA. Our SSgA -- our SPDR ETF business introduced 13 new funds during the quarter, including the SSgA Gender Diversity ETF. SHE is the first self indexed ETF, and its development was inspired by CalSTRS' efforts to move the needle on gender diversity in corporate America and seeks to track performance of the SSgA gender-diversity index, which comprises large -- U.S. large-cap companies with the highest levels within their sectors of gender diversity on their Boards of Directors and in their senior leadership.
Fourth, we are increasing our focus on expense management. Our results this quarter reflect our commitment to manage expenses, with first quarter operating expenses flat compared to the same period a year ago, and also fat -- flat excluding the seasonal impact of equity compensation for retirement-eligible employees and payroll taxes compared to the fourth quarter of 2015. We continue to make expense discipline core to our culture, encouraging employees to embrace an owner's mindset and identify ways we can reduce cost across the enterprise, looking at everything from travel to consultant spend.
As I noted earlier, State Street Beacon is contributing to our expense management efforts, and we are on track to generate at least $100 million in annualized pre-tax net run-rate expense savings this year from the program.
And fifth, we're leveraging our strong capital position to continue to return capital to shareholders. Our two -- our first quarter '16 common stock dividend was $0.34 per share, and we purchased approximately $325 million of our common stock. We expect to repurchase up to $390 million of our common stock in 2Q '16.
As I just reviewed for you, we will continue to focus our attention and effort in 2016 on our strategic priorities. We expect this will allow us to generate positive fee revenue growth and to achieve our objective of generating positive fee-basis operating leverage this year relative to 2015.
Two weeks ago, the Federal Reserve and FDIC released their review of our July 2015 RRP submission. Both the Federal Reserve and FDIC know that we have made improvements over our prior plans but determined that our 2015 resolution plan is not credible. While disappointed with the findings, we're committed to addressing the issues in advancing our resolution plan as our business and regulatory requirements evolve. We've had ongoing communications with the regulator and are focused on addressing all the deficiencies jointly identified by the Federal Reserve and the FDIC by October 1, 2016.
Now I'll turn the call over to Mike, who will review our financial performance for the first quarter, and then we'll both be available to take your questions.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Good morning, everyone.This morning, before I start my review of our operating basis results, I'd like to note that our GAAP basis results for the first quarter included pretax restructuring cost of $97 million related to State Street Be
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay. Good morning, everyone.
This morning, before I start my review of our operating basis results, I'd like to note that our GAAP basis results for the first quarter included pretax restructuring cost of $97 million related to State Street Beacon, including the exit of our futures clearing business.
Now turn to Slide 8 in the slide presentation for a summary of our operating basis results for 1Q '16. 1Q '16 results reflect softness in our fee revenue, primarily driven by lower global equity markets, partially offset by strong expense control.
Operating basis EPS for 1Q '16 decreased to $0.98 a share from $1.16 in 1Q '15 and decreased from $1.21 in 4Q '15. Our first quarter results in 2015 and 2016 included the seasonal effect of deferred incentive comp for retirement-eligible employees and payroll taxes.
Importantly, total expenses were approximately flat compared to the year-ago quarter. And excluding the noted seasonable -- seasonal retirement-eligible expenses and payroll taxes, total expenses were approximately flat compared to 4Q '15. Regarding capital in 1Q '16, we declared a common stock dividend of $0.34 a share and purchased approximately $325 million of our common stock.
Moving now to Slide 9. 1Q '16 fee revenue decreased 3.6%, while expenses were approximately flat versus a year ago. Weakness in global equity markets and elevated 1Q '15 FX revenue resulting from the Swiss National Bank actions at the time contributed to the decrease of fee revenue relative to the year-ago quarter.
I'll now turn to Slide 11 for a review of our 1Q '16 operating basis revenues. Servicing fees decreased from the year-ago quarter primarily due to the lower global equity markets and the impact of the stronger U.S. dollar, partially offset by net new business. The decrease in international equity markets, particularly in emerging markets, negatively impacted first quarter servicing fees. Compared to the year-ago quarter, average daily values for the Morgan Stanley emerging market index decreased 22%, while the equity index was down approximately 12%.
Management fees decreased relative to a year ago, reflecting global equity markets and net outflows, partially offset by lower money market fee waivers. Foreign-exchange revenue decreased from the strong market activity in 1Q '15 due to lower volatility and volumes. Nevertheless, it increased relative to 4Q '15.
Securities finance revenue increased from 1Q '15 and 4Q '15. The increase over both periods reflects increased revenue from both enhanced custody and agency lending.
Compared to 4Q '15, processing and other revenue decreased, reflecting lower equity earnings from joint ventures and lower revenues associated with tax-advantaged investments.
Moving to Slide 12, I would note that our operating basis 1Q '16 net interest revenue benefited from the higher Fed funds rate and disciplined liability pricing. Net interest revenue decreased from the year ago, primarily driven by the successful reduction in the size of our balance sheet.
Now let's turn to Slide 13 to review 1Q '16 operating basis expenses. Importantly, total operating basis expenses were well-controlled in 1Q '16 and were approximately flat relative to 1Q '15, a notable accomplishment.
Compensation and employee benefits were impacted by the seasonal deferred incentive compensation for retirement-eligible employees and payroll taxes. Demonstrating solid expense control, the other expense category decreased significantly as compared to both 1Q '15 and 4Q '15. Compared to 4Q '15, lower other expenses were driven by lower professional services fees and travel expenses as well as the settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission recorded in the fourth quarter of 2015.
Now turning to Slide 15 to review our capital position. As you can see, our capital ratios remains strong, which has enabled us to accomplish a key priority of returning capital to shareholders through dividends and common stock purchases. Compared to December 31, our common equity Tier 1 ratio increased under the Basel III fully phased-in advanced approach and remained approximately flat under the standardized approach. Importantly, the March 31 fully phased-in supplementary leverage ratio at the bank increased to 6.2%, primarily due to an increase in Tier 1 capital.
We repurchased $325 million of common stock in 1Q '16 and expect to repurchase up to $390 million in 2Q '16. This will put us approximately $65 million below our gross share repurchase program of $1.83 billion. The $65 million difference represents the reduction in our 1Q '16 equity compensation for our employees relative to what we expected at the time our capital plan was approved. The net repurchase amount is, therefore, consistent with the capital plan.
Moving onto the next slide, let me briefly discuss our agreement to acquire GE Asset Management. While it remains a top priority to return capital to shareholders through common stock repurchases and dividends, we also are focused on allocating capital to higher growth and return businesses. The agreement to acquire GE Asset Management reflects this plan. The purchase price is $435 million subject to adjustments, with up to an additional $50 million tied to incremental opportunities with GE. Excluding merger and integration charges, the transaction is expected to be accretive to operating basis EPS for the first 12-month period following the close of the transaction, and we're targeting a client asset retention rate of at least 90%. Importantly, the acquisition will significantly enhance State Street's position in the fast-growing outsourced chief investment officer market.
Moving to Slide 17. I'll now provide an update to our 2016 financial outlook. Despite the pressure on global equity markets in the first quarter, we are encouraged that the environment improved in March. Importantly, compared to January and February, servicing and management fees improved in March. On the expense front, we continue to expect operating basis expense growth of up to 2% for full year 2016 compared to full year 2015, with variability across quarters. We also continue to expect to generate positive fee operating leverage relative to 2015. Please note, my comments related to our 2016 outlook exclude any potential impact from the acquisition of GE Asset Management. Also we're on track to generate at least $100 million in estimated annual pretax net run-rate expense savings from State Street Beacon by the end of 2016.
Now as a reminder, upward pressure on regulatory and compliance cost is expected to continue throughout 2016. However, we expect the growth rate to be lower than full year 2015 relative to 2014. We also expect expense growth to be affected by the volume of new business as well as continued investments.
In addition, we continue to have 2 scenarios for 2016 net interest revenue, largely consistent with prior communications. The first scenario assumes market interest rates remain static at March 2016 levels. Under this scenario, we expect full year 2016 NIR to be in a range of approximately $2.025 billion to $2.125 billion. The second scenario assumes administered rates in the U.S. increase 25 basis points in both June and December and correspondingly, market rates to trend higher from March 2016 levels. Under this scenario, we expect full year 2016 NIR to be in a range of approximately $2.1 billion to $2.2 billion. We continue to expect the 2016 operating basis tax rate to be 30% to 32%. And lastly, I would emphasize that returning capital to shareholders through share repurchase and dividends remains a priority. Our 2016 capital plan remains subject to the results of the 2016 CCAR process, including the review by the Federal Reserve Board.
In summary, although the revenue environment remains challenging as reflected in 1Q '16 results, we're encouraged that fee revenue gained momentum in March, and we remain focused on prudently managing expenses and providing solutions to our clients.
Now, let me turn the call back over to Jay.

headline: State Street Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike.Therese, we're now available to open the call to questions.
